Sponsored post defaults","conditions":{"post_types":["tc_sponsored_post"]},"placements":{"leaderboard":"963872468","rightrail1":"963872467","mobile_leaderboard":"963872466","mobile_footer":"963909570"}},{"name":"Run of site \/ fallback","conditions":[],"placements":{"native_inriver":"93501877","native_mobile_inriver":"93501878","leaderboard":"93484975","amp_leaderboard":"963912137","rightrail1":"93484976","native_rightrail1":"963912090","native_mobile_footer":"963923619","native_rightrail2":"963913332","native_midarticle":"963922183","native_mobile_midarticle":"963922184","amp_footer":"93523784","amp_midarticle":"963923315","rightrail2":"963913913","article_footer":"963908972","mobile_leaderboard":"93484974","mobile_footer":"93484973"}}]},"assetURI":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/themes\/techcrunch-2017","breaking":"","live_event":"0","feature_islands":{"homepage":[{"id":2291966,"date":"2022-03-31T13:56:16","date_gmt":"2022-03-31T20:56:16","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2291966"},"modified":"2022-03-31T13:56:27","modified_gmt":"2022-03-31T20:56:27","slug":"co-founders-of-ukrainian-startup-delfast-discuss-navigating-through-a-crisis","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/31\/co-founders-of-ukrainian-startup-delfast-discuss-navigating-through-a-crisis\/","title":{"rendered":"Co-founders of Ukrainian startup Delfast discuss navigating through a crisis"},"content":{"rendered":" The COVID-19 pandemic<\/span> taught the world how to work from home, but Russia\u2019s war in Ukraine has taught the employees at Delfast, a Ukrainian e-bike startup, how to work from bomb shelters, while on the move and under threat of violence.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n The usual priorities of a startup \u2013 securing venture funding, researching and developing new products, finding product-market fit \u2013 haven\u2019t exactly been put on hold, but they are now much lower on Delfast\u2019s to-do list. Since Russian troops invaded Ukraine in late February, Delfast\u2019s top priority has been to see its Ukrainian team of 30 safely evacuated from the most dangerous parts of the country.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n When not focusing on sales, marketing, R&D and customer support, Delfast\u2019s smaller team of seven employees based in Los Angeles has been pleading with U.S. politicians and the European Commission to supply Ukraine with anti-aircraft missiles and fighter jets that could help Ukraine gain back some control over its air space, and, hopefully, put a stop to this war.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n Delfast\u2019s co-founders, Daniel Tonkopi and Serhiy Denysenko, say they have always believed in safeguarding the future. When they founded Delfast in 2014, originally as a delivery company, Tonkoply and Denysenko knew that providing couriers with green transportation options would be critical to the company\u2019s operations.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n \t \n\t\t \n\t\t\tThe most important thing for an entrepreneur, and in general for any leader, is to protect the team and be completely honest with them during a tough time.\t\t\t\t\t\t\tDaniel Tonkopi, co-founder of Delfast<\/cite>\n\t\t\t\t\t<\/blockquote>\n\t<\/div>\n\t<\/span><\/p>\n The founders soon realized that a bike with the power, range and battery life their couriers needed didn\u2019t exist, and so they set out to build one. In 2017, backed by a Kickstarter campaign that saw the company raise $165,000, the startup began manufacturing a bike to fit its needs \u2013 one that promptly <\/span>won the Guinness Book of World Records<\/span><\/a> for the greatest distance traveled on an electric motorbike on a single charge.<\/span><\/p>\n More recently, the Delfast Top 3.0 e-motorbike <\/span>won Forbes\u2019 fastest e-bike of the year<\/span><\/a> in 2022 after the company announced some serious <\/span>upgrades to the vehicle during CES<\/span><\/a>.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n We spoke with Delfast\u2019s co-founders to discuss what it\u2019s like running a startup during a war, how the startup is considering breaking into new business verticals, and the importance of always having a Plan B.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n The following interview, part of an ongoing series with founders who are building transportation companies, has been edited for length and clarity.\u00a0<\/span><\/i><\/p>\n Note: Serhiy Denysenko\u2019s answers were translated from Ukrainian by a member of Delfast\u2019s team for TechCrunch.\u00a0<\/span><\/i><\/p>\n TC: Serhiy, you’re on the ground in Kyiv. What’s your day-to-day like?<\/b><\/p>\n Denysenko: <\/b>Every morning starts with a check-in on Slack with all the colleagues. It\u2019s important to keep in touch and know that everyone is fine, or as fine as is possible right now.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n Besides my work as a COO, I\u2019ve been helping with volunteering, getting supplies and medicine to people, and this is something that pretty much every Ukrainian is now doing. I had my family relocated to Hungary, so I feel more or less safe, and I\u2019m just trying to work as much as possible and do my best in every possible area, whether that\u2019s supporting the company or supporting Ukraine in general.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n How are you managing your team through this crisis? What\u2019s changed?<\/b><\/p>\n Denysenko: <\/b>We got used to working remotely during Coronavirus times, so we have our task tracker, where everyone can see his or her task. Every Monday, we have an online Zoom meeting. Previously we only had these meetings at the executive level, but now during the war, we are gathering all together, just to see each other\u2019s faces and ask how they\u2019re doing, how\u2019s everyone feeling. Just to talk with everybody.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n <\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" “Every morning starts with a check-in on Slack with all the colleagues. It\u2019s important to keep in touch and know that everyone is fine, or as fine as is possible right "_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category\/576796357"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_ec_category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_ec_category=576796357"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[]]}},{"id":2292429,"date":"2022-03-31T14:08:43","date_gmt":"2022-03-31T21:08:43","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2292429"},"modified":"2022-03-31T14:26:07","modified_gmt":"2022-03-31T21:26:07","slug":"behold-the-robo-berry","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/31\/behold-the-robo-berry\/","title":{"rendered":"Behold the robo-berry"},"content":{"rendered":" If you’ve never picked a raspberry, well, first of all that’s too bad, because a fresh raspberry is a beautiful thing. But second, and more immediately relevant in this case, you would not know that there is a technique to it that, surprisingly, robots aren’t super good at because they tend to be… crushy. But this robo-berry<\/a> designed by Swiss researchers could usher in a new era of gentle, automated robo-pickers.<\/p>\n The secret to picking a raspberry is to grip it just enough to get purchase and then pull it downwards off the little stem, apparently called the “receptacle,” which seems backwards. Seems simple \u2014 and it is, but only our hands are among the most sensitive and finely controlled constructions in the universe, the culmination of a hundred million years of evolution, outdone only by (I suspect) raccoons.<\/p>\n Robots simply don’t have the senses necessary to figure out the perfect technique for picking a berry. But what if it could communicate with the berry to better sense the forces involved and avoid either a a brutal crushing or humiliating failure-to-detach?<\/p> <\/div>\n That’s what Kai Junge, a PhD student at EPFL in Switzerland, aims to accomplish with this “sensorized raspberry,” a silicone and silicon replica berry that provides feedback to the picking machine, allowing it to learn to pick faster and better \u2014 and cleaner.<\/p>\n “It\u2019s an exciting dilemma for us as robotics engineers,” said professor Josie Hughes, who worked with Junge on the project. “The raspberry harvesting season is so short, and the fruit is so valuable, that wasting them simply isn’t an option. What’s more, the cost and logistical challenges of testing different options out in the field are prohibitive. That\u2019s why we decided to run our tests in the lab and develop a replica raspberry for training harvesting robots.”<\/p>\n Apparently the hard part comes just at the moment of detaching, when the force needed to grip the berry on the receptacle suddenly becomes overkill as the object goes from solid to hollow.<\/p>\n The replica berry has a fluidic sensor that tells the system how much compression is being experienced by the silicone drooplets, allowing the control model to learn how to adjust its grip as if the berry itself is telling it how much is too much.<\/p>\n You can see the berry in action below:<\/p>\n <\/iframe><\/span><\/p>\n<p>The team plans to present their work at RobotSoft in April. And once the raspberry question is decided, they may move on to other berries, tomatoes, grapes&#8230; even apricots. The future is looking fresh!<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>If you&#8217;ve never picked a raspberry, well, first of all that&#8217;s too bad, because a fresh raspberry is a beautiful thing. But second, and more immediately relevant in this case, you would not know that there is a technique to it that, surprisingly, robots aren&#8217;t super good at because they tend to be&#8230; crushy. But He has also written for MSNBC.com, NBC News, DPReview, The Economist\/GE's Look Ahead, and others.<\/p>\n\n<p>His personal website is coldewey.cc.<\/p>","cbAvatar":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/01\/r4iwkrm6qsw3n2ximghe.jpg.jpg","twitter":"techcrunch","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/12084691"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users"}]}}],"author":[{"id":12084691,"name":"Devin Coldewey","url":"https:\/\/coldewey.cc","description":"","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/author\/devin-coldewey\/","slug":"devin-coldewey","avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/69fae9a8a3933fa91e81c086b8eee14a?s=24&d=identicon&r=g","48":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/69fae9a8a3933fa91e81c086b8eee14a?s=48&d=identicon&r=g","96":"https:\/\/secure.gravatar.com\/avatar\/69fae9a8a3933fa91e81c086b8eee14a?s=96&d=identicon&r=g"},"links":{"homepage":"http:\/\/techcrunch.com\/author\/tcdevin","twitter":"http:\/\/twitter.com\/techcrunch","linkedin":"http:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/company\/techcrunch","crunchbase":"https:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/person\/devin-coldewey"},"position":"Writer & Photographer","cbDescription":"<p>Devin Coldewey is a Seattle-based writer and photographer. coldewey.cc.<\/p>","cbAvatar":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/01\/r4iwkrm6qsw3n2ximghe.jpg.jpg","twitter":"techcrunch","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/12084691"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users"}]}}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"id":2292430,"date":"2022-03-31T11:33:03","slug":"epfl-roboberry","type":"attachment","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/31\/behold-the-robo-berry\/epfl-roboberry\/","title":{"rendered":"epfl-roboberry"},"author":12084691,"license":{"person":"EPFL"},"authors":[12084691],"caption":{"rendered":""},"alt_text":"Close-up me":"TC","slug":"tc","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/17396"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=17396"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":449550162,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/epfl\/","name":"EPFL","slug":"epfl","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449550162"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449550162"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449550162"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449550162"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449550162"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":8191,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/fruit\/","name":"fruit","slug":"fruit","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/8191"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=8191"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=8191"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=8191"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=8191"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2292389,"date":"2022-03-31T11:55:17","date_gmt":"2022-03-31T18:55:17","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2292389"},"modified":"2022-03-31T17:57:31","modified_gmt":"2022-04-01T00:57:31","slug":"all-eyes-are-on-swvl-as-it-starts-trading-on-a-spac-combination","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/31\/all-eyes-are-on-swvl-as-it-starts-trading-on-a-spac-combination\/","title":{"rendered":"All eyes are on Swvl as it starts trading on a SPAC combination"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Mass transit and shared mobility provider <a href=\"https:\/\/www.swvl.com\/\">Swvl<\/a> went public today in <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">a landmark moment for Egyptian and Middle Eastern tech ecosystems<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">. It\u2019s also a test for the company going public despite a market that\u2019s been unfriendly toward combinations with special purpose acquisition companies, or SPACs, of late.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The Egypt-born and Dubai-based company has listed its shares at $10 on the Nasdaq through a merger with U.S. women-led blank check company Queen\u2019s Gambit Growth Capital. The planned merger, which will see Swvl offer 20-30% of its total shares, was <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/07\/28\/egyptian-ride-sharing-company-swvl-plans-to-go-public-in-a-1-5b-spac-merger\/\">announced last July<\/a>.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Following closing, the combined company, now \u201cSwvl Holding Corp,\u201d will trade under GMBT and GMBTW today before switching to SWVL and SWVLW on April 1.<\/span><\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2292389\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Swvl is the first company launched from Africa and the second Middle Eastern company to list on the Nasdaq via a SPAC merger<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">. Anghami, an Abu Dhabi-based music streaming platform, <a href=\"https:\/\/eg.linkedin.com\/in\/mostafa-kandil-57761032\">did so in February<\/a> when it listed with Vistas Media Acquisition at a $220 million valuation.<\/span><\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"Q5eMhyfACo\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/07\/28\/egyptian-ride-sharing-company-swvl-plans-to-go-public-in-a-1-5b-spac-merger\/\">Egyptian ride-sharing company Swvl plans to go public in a $1.5B SPAC merger<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Egyptian ride-sharing company Swvl plans to go public in a $1.5B SPAC merger&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/07\/28\/egyptian-ride-sharing-company-swvl-plans-to-go-public-in-a-1-5b-spac-merger\/embed\/#?secret=CnJTROn2h9#?secret=Q5eMhyfACo\" data-secret=\"Q5eMhyfACo\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Swvl raised $121.5 million in private investment in public equities (PIPE) for this transaction<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">. The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), Teklas Ventures, Chimera, Agility, and Luxor Capital Group are some of its other investors. The company is currently valued at $1.5 billion.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">In February, one of its investors, Atalaya Capital, pulled out of the transaction. And in a filing, Queen\u2019s Gambit announced the termination of forward <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">purchase<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> agreements worth $100 million in SPAC shares and an extra $2 million via a private placement.<\/span><\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201cThe forward <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">purchase<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> agreement <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">was done<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> with a group, and it was <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">just<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> access to <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">additional<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> capital,\u201d Queen\u2019s Gambit Capital founder and CEO Victoria Grace told TechCrunch when asked if the termination affects the deal.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201cIts termination doesn\u2019t affect the valuation of the company or anything around our fundamental deal, which is Queen\u2019s Gambit merging with SWVL, so the valuation [stays] the same,\u201d she said.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Investors withdrawing their interests and dollars from SPACs is not peculiar to Swvl. It\u2019s a usual occurrence &#8212; for instance, when BuzzFeed went public last December, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.wsj.com\/articles\/buzzfeed-suffers-wave-of-spac-investor-withdrawals-before-going-public-11638472756\">94% of the $287.5 million raised by the SPAC <\/a><\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.wsj.com\/articles\/buzzfeed-suffers-wave-of-spac-investor-withdrawals-before-going-public-11638472756\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">was withdrawn<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> &#8212; particularly as the SPAC hype gives way in the face of an underperforming market and tighter regulation.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Despite the seeming setback, there\u2019s good news for Swvl. <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">According to CFO Youssef Salem, the company has an <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">additional $600 million from proceeds and<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> committed equity facility with B. Riley Principal to access over the next few weeks if certain conditions are met, he said.<\/span><\/p>\n<p>Swvl was founded by <a href=\"https:\/\/eg.linkedin.com\/in\/mostafa-kandil-57761032\">Mostafa Kandil<\/a>, Mahmoud Nouh and Ahmed Sabbah in 2017. The trio started the company as a bus-hailing service in Egypt and other ride-sharing services in emerging markets with fragmented public transportation.<\/p>\n<p>Its bus-hailing services enable users to make intra-state journeys by booking seats on buses running a fixed route. Swvl offerings have expanded beyond bus-hailing services, though. Now, the company offers inter-city rides, car ride-sharing, and corporate services in the 10 cities it operates in across Africa and the Middle East.<\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The partnership between Swvl and Queen\u2019s Gambit came from a mutual interest from both parties<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">. <\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">While searching for a company to <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">acquire<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, Swvl fit the blank-check company\u2019s criteria: strong business fundamentals, mobility and logistics (one of its core verticals), and an ESG ethos around women and affordable transportation.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">On the other hand<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, Swvl &#8212; off the back of raising over $170 million in venture capital, expanding to over 16 countries across Latin America, Asia and Africa; hiring executives from Facebook, Uber and Optimus; and acquiring Shotl, Viapool and door2door &#8212; was on a quest for global dominance in the mobility space. <\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A SPAC with Queen\u2019s Gambit was the most suitable option for it from a financial standpoint, and both parties feel strongly about the sustainability angle around transport &#8212; Swvl claims it has prevented approximately 289 million pounds of carbon emissions since its inception.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The company plans to expand into several countries over the next six months, including Colombia, Mexico, South Africa, and the U.S. <\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">In the meantime, all eyes will be on the company\u2019s performance as it <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">officially<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> starts trading tomorrow in a cooling SPAC market and a generally unsettled public market.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201cThere\u2019s a softness in the market, but as long as the company operates and delivers results, <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">maybe<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> today, people don\u2019t pay attention to it, but they will in months ahead,\u201d Grace said about the worrying SPAC and public markets.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201c<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">I think<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> the market will change <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">just<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> like it always does and people go back to fundamentals at how we look at company\u2019s performances. For Swvl, they have been beating every single number that was ever presented to us. And that\u2019s what makes me super excited about this. And that\u2019s the type of target you want to partner with.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"s9kBhwdIHM\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/08\/21\/almost-everything-you-need-to-know-about-spacs\/\">Almost everything you need to know about SPACs<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Almost everything you need to know about SPACs&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/08\/21\/almost-everything-you-need-to-know-about-spacs\/embed\/#?secret=dbGVg33T0n#?secret=s9kBhwdIHM\" data-secret=\"s9kBhwdIHM\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Mass transit and shared mobility provider Swvl went public today in a landmark moment for Egyptian and Middle Eastern tech ecosystems. It\u2019s also a test for the company going public despite a market that\u2019s been unfriendly toward combinations with special purpose acquisition companies, or SPACs, of late.\u00a0 The Egypt-born and Dubai-based company has listed its :"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=53067"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=53067"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=53067"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=53067"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":441094,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/chimera\/","name":"chimera","slug":"chimera","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/441094"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=441094"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=441094"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=441094"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=441094"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":21691,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/colombia\/","name":"Colombia","slug":"colombia","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/21691"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=21691"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=21691"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=21691"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=21691"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576814951,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/corporate-services\/","name":"corporate services","slug":"corporate-services","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576814951"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576814951"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576814951"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576814951"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576814951"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":52630,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/dubai\/","name":"Dubai","slug":"dubai","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/52630"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=52630"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=52630"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=52630"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=52630"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2292372,"date":"2022-03-31T12:05:44","date_gmt":"2022-03-31T19:05:44","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2292372"},"modified":"2022-03-31T13:58:42","modified_gmt":"2022-03-31T20:58:42","slug":"microsoft-acquires-process-mining-vendor-minit-to-grow-its-automation-offerings","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/31\/microsoft-acquires-process-mining-vendor-minit-to-grow-its-automation-offerings\/","title":{"rendered":"Microsoft acquires process mining vendor Minit to grow its automation offerings"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Signaling its ambitions in the process automation market, Microsoft has acquired <a href=\"https:\/\/www.minit.io\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Minit<\/a>, a Bratislava, Slovakia-originated process mining technology vendor, for an undisclosed sum, the companies announced today. Microsoft says that the purchase will &#8220;further empower&#8221; it to &#8220;help &#8230; customers digitally transform&#8221; by creating a more complete picture of their processes &#8212; and identifying which of those processes are ripe for automation.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Minit currently enables businesses to transform the way they analyze, monitor and optimize their processes. Minit\u2019s solutions have helped businesses gain deep insights into how processes run, uncover root causes of operational challenges and help mitigate undesired process outcomes,&#8221; Justin Graham, Microsoft&#8217;s general manager of process insights, wrote in a <a href=\"https:\/\/blogs.microsoft.com\/blog\/2022\/03\/31\/microsoft-acquires-minit-to-strengthen-process-mining-capabilities\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">post<\/a> on Microsoft&#8217;s corporate blog. &#8220;[With Minit, our] customers will be able to better understand their process data, uncover what operations look like in reality, and drive process standardization and improvement across the entire organization to ensure compliance at every step.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Microsoft dipped its toes into process mining with the launch of new features in Power Automate in 2019 and the acquisition of Softomotive, an RPA software provider, a year later. But with Minit, the tech giant is doubling down on a software category that could be worth over $11 billion by 2030, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.wfmz.com\/news\/pr_newswire\/pr_newswire_technology\/global-process-mining-software-market-size-value-estimated-to-reach-usd-11-096-7-million\/article_a95b3354-ec2f-5389-b761-e4dbbdadbb97.html#:~:text=According%20to%20research%20report%20published,forecast%20period%202022%20to%202030.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">according<\/a> to a report from Polaris Market Research.<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2292372\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>It wasn&#8217;t immediately clear whether the whole of the Minit team will join Microsoft &#8212; or, indeed, whether the company will remain spread across its current locations. (Minit is now headquartered in Amsterdam, with satellite offices in London and New York.) But CEO James Dening said that customers shouldn&#8217;t expect a change in the level of support they&#8217;re currently receiving.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;We are looking forward to what it means to become part of an industry leader like Microsoft and what that brings us &#8212; how we can use that scale and excellence to continue to deliver great solutions to our customers,&#8221; Dening wrote in a blog <a href=\"https:\/\/www.minit.io\/blog\/microsoft-minit-acquisition\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">post<\/a> on Minit&#8217;s website. &#8220;It has been a privilege to lead the company for the last year, and I\u2019m excited to continue my journey with the team, as part of what I consider to be the world\u2019s leading software company.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>In a statement, Microsoft spokesperson Zara Huang told TechCrunch that the Minit team will move into the\u00a0<span class=\"il\">Microsoft<\/span> Process Insights team and that there will be &#8220;no change&#8221; to the current work location of Minit team members. <span class=\"il\">Microsoft<\/span> is in early stages of determining how Minit will be integrated into its offerings, she said, and the companies will share more details when they&#8217;re available.<\/p>\n<p>Minit, which was founded in 2015 by Rasto Hlavac and had raised \u20ac10.3 million (~$11.40 million) prior to the acquisition, is one of an expanding number of startups developing process mining tools aimed at enterprise clientele. Process mining, also known as task discovery, involves spotting root cause workflow issues and bottlenecks by pulling data from systems including desktop, email apps and workflows. It&#8217;s a key part of robotic process automation (RPA), a technology that promises to automate monotonous, repetitive tasks traditionally performed by human workers while at the same time generating logs to identify potential cost savings.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>As Protocol&#8217;s Aisha Counts <a href=\"https:\/\/www.protocol.com\/bulletins\/microsoft-process-mining-minit\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">notes<\/a>, process mining has traditionally been done by system integrators who map out processes by analyzing manual workflows. Process mining software is designed to digitize the approach in a way that reduces the expense, time and effort involved.<\/p>\n<p>Underlining the appetite for process mining technologies, Celonis, a data processing company, earlier this week acquired Minit competitor Process Analytics Factory, which coincidentally integrates with Microsoft&#8217;s Power BI analytics platform. Just in the past several years, RPA vendor Automation Anywhere acquired process discovery and mining startups FortressIQ, Process Gold\\ and StepShot; Blue Prism released a task mining solution called Capture; and rivals including ABBYY and Kryon have expanded their process mining offerings.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"2NKiKfcj0k\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/29\/celonis-pushes-into-microsoft-ecosystem-with-100m-process-analytics-factory-acquisition\/\">Celonis pushes into Microsoft ecosystem with $100M Process Analytics Factory acquisition<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Celonis pushes into Microsoft ecosystem with $100M Process Analytics Factory acquisition&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/29\/celonis-pushes-into-microsoft-ecosystem-with-100m-process-analytics-factory-acquisition\/embed\/#?secret=wqSRCOP7wQ#?secret=2NKiKfcj0k\" data-secret=\"2NKiKfcj0k\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>&#8220;You know the process space is hot when even Microsoft, with its vast resources, has to buy its way in. I\u2019m sure Microsoft is seeing the same trends that we saw, which drove the combination of FortressIQ and Automation Anywhere,&#8221; Pankaj Chowdhry, EVP of discovery at Automation Anywhere and formerly CEO of FortressIQ, told TechCrunch via email. &#8220;Customers are starved for process data to help them navigate their transformation journeys and any vendor that doesn&#8217;t have best-in-class process capabilities will find itself challenged to offer a compelling solution to their customers.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Microsoft&#8217;s Minit acquisition comes at a time when the broader business process automation industry, which remains <a href=\"https:\/\/news.crunchbase.com\/news\/robotic-automation-is-back\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">flush with cash<\/a>, heads toward general consolidation. SAP acquired German process automation company Signavio in January 2021, just before ServiceNow got into the RPA segment with the buyout of India-based Intellibot.io. IBM <a href=\"https:\/\/newsroom.ibm.com\/2021-04-15-IBM-to-Acquire-myInvenio-to-help-Organizations-Use-AI-powered-Automation-to-Better-Streamline-Business-Processes\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">acquired<\/a> process mining software company MyInvenio in April. And Salesforce\u2019s MuleSoft and Microsoft followed suit with the purchases of automation tech providers <a href=\"https:\/\/venturebeat.com\/2021\/08\/02\/mulesoft-acquires-rpa-provider-servicetrace\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Servicetrace<\/a>\u00a0and\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/venturebeat.com\/2021\/10\/22\/microsoft-acquires-clear-software-to-strengthen-process-automation-offerings\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Clear Software<\/a>, respectively.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Process mining, discovery and task mining has seen a lot of transformation with many acquisitions in the last year. [It] now appears to be maturing as a market and becoming commoditized under major automation platforms,&#8221; Saikat Ray, Gartner senior research director, told TechCrunch via email. &#8220;Gartner sees an emergence of automation platform vendors offering process mining and task mining as embedded capabilities, along with RPA.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p><em>Updated at 4:15 p.m. ET, March 31, with quotes from Microsoft and Automation Anywhere.<\/em><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Signaling its ambitions in the process automation market, Microsoft has acquired Minit, a Bratislava, Slovakia-originated process mining technology vendor, for an undisclosed sum, the companies announced today. Microsoft says that the purchase will &#8220;further empower&#8221; it to &#8220;help &#8230; customers digitally transform&#8221; by creating a more complete picture of their processes &#8212; and identifying which runch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=6"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=6"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=6"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2292473,"date":"2022-03-31T14:10:50","date_gmt":"2022-03-31T21:10:50","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2292473"},"modified":"2022-03-31T14:10:57","modified_gmt":"2022-03-31T21:10:57","slug":"better-learning-through-complex-dough-manipulation","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/31\/better-learning-through-complex-dough-manipulation\/","title":{"rendered":"Better learning through &#8216;complex dough-manipulation&#8217;"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">A disproportionate number of the early industrial food-making robots we\u2019ve seen have been <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/05\/20\/robotics-roundup-12\/\">focused on pizza<\/a>. I\u2019ve long posited that this is for two key reasons. First: People like pizza. We eat a lot of it. Americans alone eat three billion pizzas a year. Second: It\u2019s relatively easy to make. The dough provides a fairly straightforward platform onto which ingredients are added.<\/p>\n<p>I say \u201cfairly\u201d here because there are still complications. There\u2019s really no such thing as easy when it comes to building robots that can execute variations on a task at a large scale. Here it\u2019s the dough that presents the problem. Turning a soft and malleable ball of dough into a pizza crust is one of those things humans have figured out how to do efficiently, but it still proves difficult for robot workers.<\/p>\n<p>A team of researchers at MIT, CMU and UC San Diego set out to create what they\u2019ve deemed \u201ccomplex dough-manipulation.\u201d The system is separated into a two-step process, in which the robot must first determine the task and then execute it using a tool like a rolling pin. The system, <a href=\"https:\/\/news.mit.edu\/2022\/robotic-deformable-object-0331\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">DiffSkill<\/a>, involves teaching robots complex tasks in simulations.<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2292473\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>MIT notes:<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>A \u201cteacher\u201d algorithm solves each step the robot must take to complete the task. Then, it trains a \u201cstudent\u201d machine-learning model that learns abstract ideas about when and how to execute each skill it needs during the task, like using a rolling pin. With this knowledge, the system reasons about how to execute the skills to complete the entire task.<\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>The researchers say the system outperformed those trained in the more traditional reinforcement learning model. \u201cOur framework provides a novel way for robots to acquire new skills. These skills can then be chained to solve more complex tasks which are beyond the capability of previous robot systems,\u201d says CSAIL grad student, Yunzhu Li.<\/p>\n<p>This is robotics, so the whole pizza thing is really an initial problem for a system designed to tackle a lot more tasks. The company points to the emerging field of eldercare robotics as a possible use going forward.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>A disproportionate number of the early industrial food-making robots we\u2019ve seen have been focused on pizza. I\u2019ve long posited that this is for two key reasons. First: People like pizza. We eat a lot of it. Americans alone eat three billion pizzas a year. Second: It\u2019s relatively easy to make. The dough provides a fairly Cribs","url":"\/shows\/tc-cribs","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1605180,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]}]},"entities":{"posts":[{"id":2292243,"date":"2022-03-31T10:00:47","date_gmt":"2022-03-31T17:00:47","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2292243"},"modified":"2022-03-31T11:32:43","modified_gmt":"2022-03-31T18:32:43","slug":"viasat-cyberattack-russian-wiper","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/31\/viasat-cyberattack-russian-wiper\/","title":{"rendered":"Viasat cyberattack blamed on Russian wiper malware"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">The recent cyberattack on U.S. satellite communications provider Viasat, an incident that triggered satellite service outages across central and eastern Europe, was likely the result of destructive wiper malware, according to newly published security research.<\/p>\n<p>Details about the cyberattack, which rendered Viasat\u2019s KA-SAT network inoperable since February 24 \u2014 the day of the Russian invasion of Ukraine \u2014 have so far been light. The attack, which also disconnected remote access to <a href=\"https:\/\/www.reuters.com\/business\/energy\/satellite-outage-knocks-out-control-enercon-wind-turbines-2022-02-28\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">about 5,800 wind turbines across Germany<\/a>, was originally believed to be the result of a distributed denial of service attack, but SentinelLabs researchers now believe it was the result of a new strain of wiper malware called \u201cAcidRain\u201d that was designed to remotely erase vulnerable modems and routers.<\/p>\n<p>AcidRain\u00a0was <a href=\"https:\/\/www.sentinelone.com\/labs\/acidrain-a-modem-wiper-rains-down-on-europe\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">discovered by SentinelLabs researchers<\/a> on March 15 after it was uploaded to VirusTotal from a user in Italy with the name &#8220;ukrop,&#8221; which the researchers say could be shorthand for &#8220;Ukraine operation.&#8221; The wiper&#8217;s functionality is described as \u201cgeneric\u201d by the researchers, in that it performs an in-depth wipe of the filesystem and various known storage device files, before attempting to destroy the data. Once the wiping processes are complete, the device is rebooted and ultimately rendered inoperable.<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2292243\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>\u201cAcidRain\u2019s functionality is relatively straightforward and takes a bruteforce attempt that possibly signifies that the attackers were either unfamiliar with the particulars of the target firmware or wanted the tool to remain generic and reusable,\u201d said SentinelLabs researchers\u00a0Juan Andres Guerrero-Saade and Max van Amerongen.<\/p>\n<p>While the identity of the attackers remains unknown, SentinelLabs has noted similarities between AcidRain and the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/10\/04\/uk-says-russias-gru-was-behind-a-spate-of-chaotic-cyber-attacks-between-2015-and-2017\/\">VPNFilter malware<\/a>, which infected thousands of home and small business routers and network devices worldwide. In 2018, the FBI attributed the VPNFilter operation to <a href=\"https:\/\/www.cybersecobservatory.com\/2018\/05\/29\/fbi-warns-russians-hacked-hundreds-thousands-routers\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">the Russian-backed &#8220;Fancy Bear&#8221; \u2014 or APT28 \u2014 hacking group<\/a>, and more recently, the NSA and CISA tied it to Sandworm, which has been accused of a five-year spree of attacks, including the destructive <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/notpetya\/\">NotPetya<\/a> cyberattack that targeted hundreds of firms and hospitals worldwide and cyberattacks that took down part of the Ukrainian power grid. Both APT28 and Sandworm have been linked to Russia\u2019s military intelligence agency, the GRU.<\/p>\n<p>The researchers note that while it \u201ccannot definitively\u201d tie AcidRain to VPNFilter, or the larger Sandworm threat cluster, it notes \u201ca medium-confidence assessment of non-trivial developmental similarities between their components.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>AcidRain is believed to be the seventh strain of\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/02\/28\/fbi-cisa-ukraine-wiper-malware\/\">wiper malware to target Ukraine<\/a> since the onset of Russia\u2019s invasion, the researcher said.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Viasat confirmed much of SentinelOne&#8217;s findings in a statement given to TechCrunch. Viasaid said the researchers&#8217; findings are &#8220;consistent with the facts in our report,&#8221; which it released Wednesday, but declined to comment further citing an ongoing investigation.<\/p>\n<p>Viasat said on Wednesday in its first incident response report regarding the February cyberattack that the unnamed attackers exploited a misconfigured VPN appliance to gain remote access to the &#8220;trusted management&#8221; segment of the KA-SAT network, before using their access to \u201cexecute legitimate, targeted management commands on a large number of residential modems simultaneously.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Viasat goes on to add that \u201cthese destructive commands overwrote key data in flash memory on the modems, rendering the modems unable to access the network, but not permanently unusable.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>SentineLabs notes in its report that it remains unclear how legitimate commands could have such a disruptive effect on the modems. \u201cDespite Viasat\u2019s statement claiming that there was no supply-chain attack or use of malicious code on the affected routers, we posit the more plausible hypothesis that the attackers deployed AcidRain (and perhaps other binaries and scripts) to these devices in order to conduct their operation,&#8221;\u00a0Guerrero-Saade and van Amerongen concluded.<\/p>\n<p>Since the February attack, which Viasat says impacted several thousand customers located in Ukraine and tens of thousands of customers across Europe, the company has shipped almost 30,000 modems to distributors to bring customers back online. The outage has not yet been fully resolved, and <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/18\/cisa-fbi-satellite-networks\/\">CISA and the FBI have warned that US satellites could be the next target<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p><em>Updated with comment from Viasat.\u00a0<\/em><\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"8yXTSaGoUF\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/18\/cisa-fbi-satellite-networks\/\">CISA, FBI warn of threats to US satellite networks after Viasat cyberattack<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;CISA, FBI warn of threats to US satellite networks after Viasat cyberattack&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/18\/cisa-fbi-satellite-networks\/embed\/#?secret=12P3BDhRrE#?secret=8yXTSaGoUF\" data-secret=\"8yXTSaGoUF\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>The recent cyberattack on U.S. satellite communications provider Viasat, an incident that triggered satellite service outages across central and eastern Europe, was likely the result of destructive wiper malware, according to newly published security research. Details about the cyberattack, which rendered Viasat\u2019s KA-SAT network inoperable since February 24 \u2014 the day of the Russian invasion [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574469,"featured_media":2292281,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"0bd5b74e-38e8-3020-8235-401a64c407ec"},"categories":[21587494],"tags":[113937,262,141615,61138,51751,1188524,32060,449557099,576596288,231892,52842,3550,419,41339,10759,576626199,576598345,22735,449557049,449549004,13847,1558651],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/GettyImages-161185869.jpg","parsely":{"version":"1.0.0","meta":{"@context":"http:\/\/schema.org","@type":"WebPage","headline":"Viasat and JetBlue Technology Ventures talk VC climate tech and ESG at TC Sessions: Climate 2022"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Investment in climate tech is heating up almost as fast as climate change itself. In 2021, <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/02\/23\/climate-investment\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">climate tech startups received $40+ billion<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> across more than 600 deals. That\u2019s more than double the capital investment made in 2020.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">As <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.spglobal.com\/esg\/insights\/key-esg-trends-in-2022\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">S&amp;P Global recently reported<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, corporate sustainability efforts are under increasing scrutiny from investors, regulators and the public at large \u2014 placing corporations in the spotlight to actually behave differently. As a result, many corporate venture capital firms \u2014 particularly those with strong Environmental Social Governance (ESG) policies \u2014 are increasingly interested in startups focused on climate change tech.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Our existential climate crisis, the climate tech that could mitigate it and the VCs committed to funding it will intersect in two different presentations at <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-sessions-climate-2022\/?utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=climate2022&amp;utm_content=sosvjetblue&amp;utm_source=techcrunch&amp;promo=article03&amp;display=\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">TC Sessions: Climate 2022<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> (presented by Extreme Tech Challenge) in Berkeley, California on June 14.\u00a0<\/span><\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2290943\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">We\u2019re thrilled to announce that Amy Burr, president of JetBlue Technology Ventures (JTV), and Pae Wu, partner at SOSV and CTO at IndieBio, will helm two different panels addressing climate tech investment, corporate social responsibility (CSR) and ESG.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Burr leads JTV at a time when JetBlue has increased its measurable steps to reduce its effects on climate change and to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2040. Among other efforts, and a first for JetBlue, the company now ties <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.esgtoday.com\/jetblue-ties-senior-bonuses-to-esg-goals-launches-2040-net-zero-target\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">ESG targets to bonuses<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> for its senior leaders.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">As president, Burr shapes the strategic venture investment direction of JetBlue and facilitates integration of successful startup programs into the airline\u2019s overall corporate innovation initiatives. A sample of JTV\u2019s portfolio companies include Joby (trading publicly), Lacuna, Turnkey (acquired) and Universal Hydrogen.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Prior to joining JTV, Burr \u2014 one of the original founders of Virgin America \u2014 served at VX in various executive roles and led the merger integration with Alaska Airlines.<\/span><\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">At both SOSV and IndieBio, Wu is responsible for portfolio management and technical oversight. She\u2019s focused on funding early-stage climate startups, along with tracking the trends and timing of hot, climate-specific industries. A sample of SOVO portfolio companies include Apix, New Age Meats, Perfect Day and Re-Nuble.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Prior to joining IndieBio, Wu served as the scientific director of Alpha, Telef\u00f3nica\u2019s Barcelona-based moonshot factory. Her earlier career includes stints as science director at the U.S. Office of Naval Research (Global) and as a technical consultant at the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA).\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Don\u2019t miss this opportunity to hear from JTV\u2019s Amy Burr and SOSV\u2019s Pae Wu. You\u2019ll gain a deeper understanding of how investors think when it comes to investing in climate tech, and you\u2019ll learn how to \u2014 and why you should \u2014 build ESG policies into your startup from day one.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-sessions-climate-2022\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">TC Sessions: Climate 2022<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> is all about the growing wave of startups, technologies, scientists and engineers dedicated to saving our planet and, of course, the investors who finance them. Join us in-person on June 14 at UC Berkeley&#8217;s Zellerbach Auditorium. <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-sessions-climate-2022\/?utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=climate2022&amp;utm_content=sosvjetblue&amp;utm_source=techcrunch&amp;promo=article03&amp;display=\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Register now and save $200<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">.<\/span><\/p>\n<p>\t<iframe\n\t\t\tid=\"wpcom-iframe-c579bf66071470c941415771998cda42\"\n\t\t\twidth=\"100%\"\n\t\t\theight=\"900\"\n\t\t\tsrc=\"https:\/\/tcprotectedembed.com\/protected-iframe\/c579bf66071470c941415771998cda42\"\n\t\t\tscrolling=\"true\"\n\t\t\tframeborder=\"0\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"bizzabo\"\n\t>\n\t<\/iframe>\n\t<script Sessions: Climate 2022","slug":"tc-sessions-climate-2022","taxonomy":"tc_event","rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event\/576959288"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_event"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event\/449559507"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_event=576959288"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_events?tc_event=576959288"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tc_event=576959288"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}]]}},{"id":2292192,"date":"2022-03-31T10:00:11","date_gmt":"2022-03-31T17:00:11","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2292192"},"modified":"2022-03-31T11:53:31","modified_gmt":"2022-03-31T18:53:31","slug":"apple-business-essentials-puts-device-management-and-support-in-reach-of-smbs","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/31\/apple-business-essentials-puts-device-management-and-support-in-reach-of-smbs\/","title":{"rendered":"New Apple program puts device management, support in reach of SMBs"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Managing Apple devices can be a chore for small businesses &#8212; it takes time to set up each device, and it can be difficult to manage them in the field without being invasive, especially when it comes to &#8220;bring your own&#8221; devices.<\/p>\n<p>Last year, Apple <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/11\/10\/apple-introduces-device-management-solution-aimed-at-small-business\/\">introduced a new program<\/a> in beta called <a href=\"https:\/\/www.apple.com\/business\/essentials\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Apple Business Essentials<\/a> designed to help small businesses solve this issue, and today the company announced that it was now open for any legitimate small business to sign up in the U.S.<\/p>\n<p>As Susan Prescott, Apple\u2019s vice president of enterprise and education marketing put it, small business owners aren&#8217;t IT pros and this gives them an easier way to manage Apple devices.<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2292192\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>&#8220;As these businesses grow, so do the demands on their time. If you have more employees, you&#8217;re likely to have more devices. And that can mean time dealing with managing those devices, whether it&#8217;s set up, being lost, etc. So we felt like we were in a position to help by providing a really easy solution that helps small businesses stay focused on running their businesses,&#8221; Prescott said.<\/p>\n<p>The program includes a few components. For starters, it enables small businesses to easily enroll new devices, including installing a set of business applications. You can organize your setup with a base set of applications that every device in the company will get, and then you can refine that for each department or group with specific tools for each one, such as marketing, sales and so forth, or however you choose to organize them.<\/p>\n<p>Users access these apps via a Business Essentials app on their devices. They can have multiple devices and each has the same set of apps. When they double-click or tap the Business Essentials app, they go into a business desktop where they can access the apps assigned to them. Businesses also have the option of connecting to their single sign-on system, whatever that happens to be. This approach keeps personal data completely separate when employees are bringing their own devices while giving employees a familiar set of tools.<\/p>\n<p>Admins also have the option of forcing updates when desirable (like an essential security update) and can offer support for company or BYODs. The latter comes from an accompanying AppleCare+ for Business Essentials package. That includes 24\/7 access to Apple support and onsite repair in up to four hours, which is a pretty high-end service for small businesses.<\/p>\n<p>Each package that includes the service component comes with up to two repair credits, which companies can use to get service without having the employee or the customer swipe a credit card. What&#8217;s more, customers can pool these credits as they aren&#8217;t necessarily associated with the individual account. If the person leaves the company, however, repair credits get subtracted from the total.<\/p>\n<p>This level of device management is typically only available for much larger businesses. By giving smaller businesses access to this program, Apple is putting it within reach of SMBs, helping to free them up from IT administration chores, which are typically outside their areas of expertise, allowing them to concentrate more on other essential business tasks.<\/p>\n<p>Pricing is based on the number of devices and amount of storage, starting at $2.99 for one device with 50 GB of storage. If you want AppleCare+ along with a particular subscription type, that will cost you substantially more.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2292457\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2292457\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2292457\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Screen-Shot-2022-03-31-at-2.52.09-PM.jpg?w=680\" alt=\"Apple pricing\" width=\"680\" height=\"323\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Screen-Shot-2022-03-31-at-2.52.09-PM.jpg 2246w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Screen-Shot-2022-03-31-at-2.52.09-PM.jpg?resize=150,71 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Screen-Shot-2022-03-31-at-2.52.09-PM.jpg?resize=300,142 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Screen-Shot-2022-03-31-at-2.52.09-PM.jpg?resize=768,365 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Screen-Shot-2022-03-31-at-2.52.09-PM.jpg?resize=680,323 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Screen-Shot-2022-03-31-at-2.52.09-PM.jpg?resize=1536,729 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Screen-Shot-2022-03-31-at-2.52.09-PM.jpg?resize=2048,972 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Screen-Shot-2022-03-31-at-2.52.09-PM.jpg?resize=50,24 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2292457\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Apple<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>It&#8217;s worth noting that the device management component came at least in part from <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/06\/24\/apple-has-acquired-fleetsmith-a-startup-that-helps-it-manage-apple-devices-remotely\/\">the Fleetsmith acquisition<\/a> in 2020.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Managing Apple devices can be a chore for small businesses &#8212; it takes time to set up each device, and it can be difficult to manage them in the field without being invasive, especially when it comes to &#8220;bring your own&#8221; devices. Last year, Apple introduced a new program in beta called Apple Business Essentials things first-time founders must remember when working with VCs"},"content":{"rendered":"<div class=\"article__contributor-byline-wrapper\">\n<div class=\"article__contributor-byline\">\n\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__contributor\">\n\t\t<div class=\"byline__author\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"byline__author-name\">Zach DeWitt<\/span>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"byline__author-title\" style=\"display: block;\">Contributor<\/span>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"contributor__twitter\">\n\t\t\t<a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/ZacharyDeWitt\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<svg class=\"icon icon--twitter icon--white\" viewBox=\"0 0 20 20\" version=\"1.1\" aria-labelledby=\"title\">\n\t\t<title>Share on Twitter<\/title>\n\t\t<path d=\"M20,4c-0.7,0.3-1.5,0.6-2.4,0.7c0.9-0.5,1.5-1.4,1.8-2.3c-0.8,0.5-1.7,0.8-2.6,1C16.1,2.5,15,2,13.8,2c-2.3,0-4.1,1.9-4.1,4.2c0,0.3,0,0.7,0.1,1C6.4,7,3.4,5.4,1.4,2.9C1,3.5,0.8,4.1,0.8,4.9c0,1.4,0.7,2.7,1.8,3.5C2,8.4,1.4,8.2,0.8,7.9v0.1c0,2,1.4,3.7,3.3,4.1c-0.4,0.1-0.7,0.2-1.1,0.2c-0.3,0-0.5,0-0.8-0.1c0.5,1.7,2,2.9,3.8,2.9c-1.4,1.1-3.2,2-5.1,2c-0.3,0-0.7,0-1-0.1c1.8,1.2,4,1.7,6.3,1.7c7.5,0,11.7-6.4,11.7-12V6.1C18.8,5.6,19.4,4.8,20,4z\"\/>\t<\/svg>\n\t\t\t\t<\/a>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\t\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__bio\">\n\t\tAs a partner at Wing Venture Capital, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.wing.vc\/people\/zach-dewitt\">Zach Dewitt<\/a> focuses on early-stage investments in transformative enterprise technologies.\t<\/div>\n\t\n\t<\/div>\n<\/div><p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">After winning the<\/span> <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/boston-meetup\/?_ga=2.63138347.584704528.1628113771-537177162.1628113771\">2013 TechCrunch Meetup and Pitch-off<\/a>, I decided to drop out of business school to pursue my <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2013\/11\/15\/boston-pitch-off-winner-drop-lets-you-leave-surprise-messages-all-over-town\/\">startup<\/a> full time. Two years and two award-winning iPhone apps later, we ultimately decided it was time to sell our technology to Snapchat.<\/p>\n<p>At that point, I went back to Harvard to finish up my MBA, and after graduation, I joined an early-stage venture capital firm based in Palo Alto.<\/p>\n<p>Through my startup experience and having now invested in more than 10 startups with Wing, what I\u2019ve come to learn is that finding the right venture capitalist for your startup is one of the most important decisions you\u2019ll make. In many ways, it\u2019s like finding the right spouse.<\/p>\n<p>A great VC will do so much more for you than just write a check. You want someone with a high degree of empathy and curiosity who will ask the right questions and challenge you, while also being a shock absorber for bad news. VCs should never give armchair product advice nor cross the line into micromanagement.<\/p>\n<p>\t<div class=\"article-block block--pullout block--right\">\n\t\t<blockquote>\n\t\t\tConsistent communication is important, but it\u2019s not just a matter of throwing a recurring meeting on the calendar.\t\t\t\t\t<\/blockquote>\n\t<\/div>\n\t<\/p>\n<p>The best founder and VC relationships are based on trust and partnership; it should be a relationship that&#8217;s nonjudgmental, supportive, and constructive. As many founders can attest, the startup journey can be lonely at times. Having a true partner to help you steer the ship when the sailing is smooth or otherwise can be a game-changer.<\/p>\n<p>Here are some pieces of advice that I\u2019d give to founders about how to choose the right VC and get the best out of the relationship.<\/p>\n<h2>Choose someone who can help with your blind spots<\/h2>\n<p>As a founder, it\u2019s easy to get bogged down by details. In my case, I was so focused on the product experience that I didn\u2019t think through other strategic initiatives like marketing, partnerships, or, at times, fundraising.<\/p>\n<p>For example, it was only after being prompted by an investor that I started putting time and energy into strengthening my relationship with Apple to get our app featured in the Apple Store. This App Store feature changed the company\u2019s trajectory, and it came as a result of an investor making an introduction to Apple.<\/p>\n<p><div day left to save $300 on your pass to TC Sessions: Mobility 2022"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">We\u2019re starting the final countdown on serious early-bird savings for passes to <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-sessions-mobility-2022\/?utm_medium=tc_article_15&amp;utm_campaign=mobility2022&amp;utm_content=tc_article_15&amp;utm_source=techcrunch&amp;promo=tcarticle15&amp;display=\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">TC Sessions: Mobility 2022<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> on May 18-19 in San Mateo, California with online analyst commentary on May 20. It\u2019s the must-see mobility event of the year, and you have one last day to save $300 on the price of admission.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">This is a move-it-or-lose-it situation, people. <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-sessions-mobility-2022\/?utm_medium=tc_article_15&amp;utm_campaign=mobility2022&amp;utm_content=tc_article_15&amp;utm_source=techcrunch&amp;promo=tcarticle15#tickets\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Buy your early-bird pass<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> by <\/span><b>11:59 pm (PT) on Friday, April 1<\/b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, and you\u2019ll save $300. It\u2019s really that simple.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Here\u2019s a quick reminder of what goes on and why you don\u2019t want to miss out. The FOMO is real. <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">You\u2019ll hear and learn from mobility\u2019s leading founders, CEOs, VCs and policymakers as TechCrunch editors shove the hype aside to ask tough, thought-provoking questions during one-on-one interviews, panel discussions and fireside chats.<\/span><\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2289660\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">You\u2019ll walk away with a deeper understanding of trends and market influences that can help you position your business for success. Here\u2019s what serial entrepreneur Parug Demircioglu, CEO at Invemo and a partner at Nito Bikes, told us about his experience.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201cWe were planning to launch Nito Bikes in the U.S., and the conference was an excellent opportunity to gain a solid grasp of the micromobility space. We heard from industry experts, learned about current and future trends and checked out the competition. I thoroughly enjoyed the experience.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Don\u2019t skip the smaller, topic-focused roundtable discussions. They let you really dig into a subject, connect with other founders and expand your network.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">We\u2019re expecting more than 2,000 attendees, but you\u2019ll have plenty of space and breathing room in the 50,000-square-foot venue that includes indoor and outdoor expo areas. Explore all the early-stage startups showcasing their tech, talent and \u2014 get ready \u2014 test drive the latest new e-scooters, e-bikes and autonomous vehicles. All work and no play? Not a chance.<\/span><\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-sessions-mobility-2022\/?utm_medium=tc_article_15&amp;utm_campaign=mobility2022&amp;utm_content=tc_article_15&amp;utm_source=techcrunch&amp;promo=tcarticle15&amp;display=\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">TC Sessions: Mobility 2022<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> takes place on May 18-19 in San Mateo, California with online analyst commentary on May 20. Sessions: Mobility 2022","slug":"tc-sessions-mobility-2022","taxonomy":"tc_event","rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event\/576980503"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_event"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event\/449559507"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_event=576980503"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_events?tc_event=576980503"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tc_event=576980503"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}]]}},{"id":2292185,"date":"2022-03-31T09:03:21","date_gmt":"2022-03-31T16:03:21","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2292185"},"modified":"2022-03-31T10:21:59","modified_gmt":"2022-03-31T17:21:59","slug":"youtube-tv-finally-adds-picture-in-picture-support-on-ios-youtube-support-expected-in-coming-months","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/31\/youtube-tv-finally-adds-picture-in-picture-support-on-ios-youtube-support-expected-in-coming-months\/","title":{"rendered":"YouTube TV finally adds picture-in-picture support on iOS; YouTube support expected in &#8216;coming months&#8217;"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">YouTube TV is catching up to other streaming apps including Netflix, Hulu, HBO Max, Prime Video and others by finally adding support for picture-in-picture on iOS devices running iOS 15 or higher. First introduced to iPad users with iOS 13 then to <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/06\/22\/apple-unveils-ios-14-with-home-screen-widgets\/\">iPhone with iOS 14 in 2020<\/a>, YouTube has been slow to adopt this now standard functionality that allows users to stream videos in a small, floating miniplayer on their homescreen while multitasking on their device.<\/p>\n<p>To try out the new functionality with the YouTube TV streaming service, users first select a title they want to play then swipe up from the bottom of the screen to enable the picture-in-picture mode, the company <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/YouTubeTV\/status\/1509262940708478981\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">explained in a tweet<\/a> announcing the news on Wednesday. YouTube said the feature was &#8220;slowly rolling out,&#8221; so not all users may see the option immediately.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">iPhone &amp; iPad users \ud83d\udd0a <\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2292185\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>We\u2019re happy to share that picture-in-picture is now rolling out to your iOS 15+ devices. Simply select a video to watch and swipe \u2b06\ufe0f from the bottom of the screen to return to the device&#39;s homepage. The video can scale down and move across your screen.<\/p>\n<p>&mdash; YouTube TV (@YouTubeTV) <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/YouTubeTV\/status\/1509262940708478981?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">March 30, 2022<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<p>Users have been frustrated that YouTube has taken so long to implement this now-basic functionality. There is some speculation that this delay has to do with how the YouTube player on iOS has been designed for serving and tracking ads &#8212; a core aspect of YouTube&#8217;s business and one which some other streamers &#8212; like Netflix and Amazon &#8212;\u00a0 wouldn&#8217;t have to contend with.<\/p>\n<p>This seems like a probable explanation, given that YouTube didn&#8217;t simply add the option for picture-in-picture (PiP) as other video apps have done, but rather <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/08\/26\/youtube-to-roll-out-picture-in-picture-viewing-for-all-u-s-ios-users-starting-with-premium-subscribers\/\">has been &#8220;testing&#8221; the feature since last August<\/a> with Premium subscribers as part of its YouTube &#8220;experiments.&#8221; In 2020, YouTube had made opting into tests of upcoming features called &#8220;experiments&#8221; a perk for its Premium subscribers. Last year, YouTube began testing PiP on the iOS YouTube app with subscribers in the U.S. Now, according to <a href=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/new\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">YouTube&#8217;s experiments website<\/a>, those tests continue. On the site today, YouTube says the current test will be available until April 8.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Unfortunately, that test&#8217;s end date may not mean YouTube will add PiP support on iOS shortly thereafter. Pushed for some sort of sense as to when YouTube users would be able to access this feature, a spokesperson told TechCrunch the company aims to make PiP support available to all YouTube users on iOS &#8212; including both free users and Premium subscribers &#8212; in the &#8220;coming months.&#8221; <em>Sigh.\u00a0<\/em><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>YouTube TV is catching up to other streaming apps including Netflix, Hulu, HBO Max, Prime Video and others by finally adding support for picture-in-picture on iOS devices running iOS 15 or higher. First introduced to iPad users with iOS 13 then to iPhone with iOS 14 in 2020, YouTube has been slow to adopt this
