/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=135234"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=135234"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=135234"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":15108,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/player\/","name":"player","slug":"player","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/15108"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=15108"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=15108"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=15108"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=15108"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":11373,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/premium\/","name":"Premium","slug":"premium","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/11373"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=11373"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=11373"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=11373"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=11373"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":38616,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/smartphones\/","name":"smartphones","slug":"smartphones","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/38616"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=38616"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=38616"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=38616"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=38616"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2292152,"date":"2022-03-31T09:00:58","date_gmt":"2022-03-31T16:00:58","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2292152"},"modified":"2022-03-31T10:34:48","modified_gmt":"2022-03-31T17:34:48","slug":"antimatter-raises-12m-series-a-to-help-saas-companies-keep-their-customer-data-secure","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/31\/antimatter-raises-12m-series-a-to-help-saas-companies-keep-their-customer-data-secure\/","title":{"rendered":"Antimatter raises $12M Series A to help SaaS companies keep their customer data secure"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">With SaaS becoming the standard for most business software, the security demands on SaaS companies are constantly increasing. Add users who need their data sandboxed from others or kept in a specific geographic region and the workload for development and security teams only increases. <a href=\"https:\/\/www.antimatter.io\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Antimatter<\/a>, which is coming out of stealth today and launching its service into private beta, offers a different kind of solution to these problems. It provides SaaS companies with the cryptographic infrastructure that can provably guarantee that a service meets their residency, governance and tenancy requirements, using secure enclaves that keeps data encrypted in transit, at rest and during execution.<\/p>\n<p>The company also today announced that it has raised a $12 million Series A round led by NEA, with participation from General Catalyst and UNION Labs. The founders of Snowflake, Okta, Dropbox, VMware, Segment and Databricks also participated in this round.<\/p>\n<p>The company was <a href=\"https:\/\/www.antimatter.io\/team\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">co-founded<\/a> by Andrew Krioukov (CEO), the former founder and CEO of workplace management service <a href=\"https:\/\/comfyapp.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Comfy<\/a> (which Siemens acquired in 2018); Michael Andersen (CTO), the group&#8217;s cryptography specialist who, like Krioukov, has a PhD in Computer Science from Berkeley; and Beau Trincia (VP of Design), who was also on the founding team at Comfy and spent seven years working on user experience design and product at <a href=\"https:\/\/www.ideo.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">IDEO<\/a>.<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2292152\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>During the experience of building Comfy, Krioukov and Trincia themselves faced the problem of having to protect the user data of large enterprise customers like Microsoft, BMW, Salesforce and SAP. &#8220;That was really hard,&#8221; said Krioukov. &#8220;It took a lot of engineering time. It took a lot of sales time to try to talk through all this. It delayed &#8212; and even killed &#8212; some sales for us.&#8221; After talking to Andersen, the team realized that they had the right ingredients to solve this problem once and for all, Krioukov explained.<\/p>\n<p>At the same time, companies increasingly want more control over their data, even if it is under the auspice of a SaaS company, but it is very hard for SaaS companies to do that. &#8220;We realized we had a breakthrough and we could come up with a new solution that is a really different cloud deployment architecture that gives strong guarantees to the buyers and then allows the SaaS vendors to speed up their sales and offer cryptographic proof,&#8221; said Krioukov.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2292226\" style=\"width: 976px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/anitmatter_diagram.jpg\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2292226\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2292226\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/anitmatter_diagram.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"966\" height=\"668\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/anitmatter_diagram.jpg 966w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/anitmatter_diagram.jpg?resize=150,104 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/anitmatter_diagram.jpg?resize=300,207 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/anitmatter_diagram.jpg?resize=768,531 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/anitmatter_diagram.jpg?resize=680,470 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/anitmatter_diagram.jpg?resize=50,35 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 966px) 100vw, 966px\" \/><\/a><p id=\"caption-attachment-2292226\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Anitmatter<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>With Antimatter&#8217;s solution, the data sits in secure enclaves within Kubernetes and the company then uses that to give hardware guarantees that the data is always encrypted, even while being processed. &#8220;This gives SaaS vendors a way to prove that their customer data is secure &#8212; secure to a higher standard than anyone has ever really aimed for before because the app could be malicious, the employees could be malicious, all these things could go wrong &#8212; and the customer data would still be provably secure,&#8221; explained Andersen.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>He also noted that there is no performance impact when the SaaS application works with that private data inside the secure enclave. There is also no need to make code changes to the SaaS app. Antimatter&#8217;s service simply slots in underneath the app, as Andersen explained, and provides these guarantees because no unencrypted data can exit the enclave &#8212; and the hardware then guarantees that nobody can read the memory of the server either. All of the major clouds now offer some version of secure enclave thanks to the cryptographic features of modern server chips. Though as the team noted, that&#8217;s a great primitive to work from but doesn&#8217;t provide the kinds of guarantees Antimatter provides to its customers.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2292159\" style=\"width: 310px\" class=\"wp-caption alignright\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2292159\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2292159 size-medium\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Antimatter_gradient_background_rect0.4x.png?w=300\" alt=\"\" width=\"300\" height=\"150\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Antimatter_gradient_background_rect0.4x.png 400w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Antimatter_gradient_background_rect0.4x.png?resize=150,75 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Antimatter_gradient_background_rect0.4x.png?resize=300,150 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Antimatter_gradient_background_rect0.4x.png?resize=50,25 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2292159\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Antimatter<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>It&#8217;s worth highlighting that with Beau Trincia, the team has a design-focused co-founder, something we don&#8217;t often see for these kinds of highly technical problems. But as Trincia noted, right from the outset, the team wanted to make sure it designed the right experiences for the services&#8217; target audiences. That may be the CTO who makes the final purchase decision but he also noted that the team wanted to build an intuitive user experience for the developers, as well as good user experience for those users inside a company that should (or shouldn&#8217;t) have access to this data. He also noted that part of the design challenge here is to show users that their data is indeed secure. &#8220;Being able to show people that events did or didn&#8217;t happen &#8212; and kind of really clearly explaining that and having an awesome dashboard for giving people that visibility [is important],&#8221; Trincia said.<\/p>\n<p>Like most companies at this stage, the team plans to use the new funding to expand the development team as it looks to open up its service to a wider audience soon.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cThe crypto tech and years of university R&amp;D that serve as Antimatter\u2019s foundation are a gigantic step forward for highly usable \u2014 yet provably correct \u2014 secure computing and data privacy,&#8221; said NEA venture partner Greg Papadopoulos. &#8220;We\u2019re super excited to partner with Andrew and the team as they empower companies to definitively secure customer computing and data.\u201d<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>With SaaS becoming the standard for most business software, the security demands on SaaS companies are constantly increasing. Add users who need their data sandboxed from others or kept in a specific geographic region and the workload for development and security teams only increases. Antimatter, which is coming out of stealth today and launching its [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":34511731,"featured_media":2292158,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"b5018f0d-0f14-3866-a809-db67f2497fc5"},"categories":[24405894,14911,449557044,60523764,576602979,21587494,20429,17396],"tags":[576940153,576613741,71772,449554827,1715866,346693,262,25818,195273147,2123095,1677681,892510,637,30135,42674,97017,31099,448437081,21219,581,194471,38600],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Antimatter_founder_team_table_large.png","parsely":{"version":"1.0.0","meta":{"@context":"http:\/\/schema.org","@type":"WebPage","headline":"6 f":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/2123095"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=2123095"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=2123095"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=2123095"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=2123095"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2291768,"date":"2022-03-31T09:00:53","date_gmt":"2022-03-31T16:00:53","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2291768"},"modified":"2022-03-30T13:53:15","modified_gmt":"2022-03-30T20:53:15","slug":"as-right-to-repair-legislation-looms-samsung-introduces-self-service-for-galaxy-devices","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/31\/as-right-to-repair-legislation-looms-samsung-introduces-self-service-for-galaxy-devices\/","title":{"rendered":"As right to repair legislation looms, Samsung introduces \u2018self-service\u2019 for Galaxy devices"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Last year, Apple proved it could still surprise when it announced a Self Service Repair plan. The offering is still limited, and the company &#8212; as ever &#8212; recommends users take their products in to get fixed, rather than potentially damaging them further. Even so, it marked a major shift for a company that has mostly frowned on <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/right-to-repair\/\">self-repair<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>This morning, Samsung announced its own take on the category. The new program kicks off for Galaxy S20, S21 and Tab S7+ owners, offering tools, parts and guides to repair things like displays, back glass and charging ports. The company plans to continue adding additional phones to the lineup, going forward. My suspicion is we won\u2019t be seeing foldable display panels added to the list, due to their relative complexity, but time will tell.<\/p>\n<p>Interestingly, the news finds Samsung partnering with the teardown specialists at iFixit. It\u2019s not a dig at Apple exactly, though the iPhone maker has been dinged over repairability issues quiet a bit over the years. Though the site did credit Apple\u2019s decision last year, noting, \u201cApple is finally acknowledging that lots of us have the technical know-how to fix our own stuff.\u201d<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2291768\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>Per the Samsung deal, iFixit CEO Kyle Wiens notes, \u201cWe are excited to be consulting with Samsung to help them develop a solution for DIY parts and repair Information. Every time you fix a device, you\u2019re helping the planet.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>That last bit is, naturally, a big selling point in the press material surrounding this news. Samsung has been making a lot of noise around sustainability in recent years, including a reduction in packaging and utilizing more repurposed materials in its devices. Of course, the most surefire way to eliminate e-waste is simply building and buying fewer electronics. User-repairability &#8212; if done right &#8212; can extend the life of existing products.<\/p>\n<p>The big shadow looming over all of this is possible legislation being introduced both nationally and in state senates designed to give consumers more power. The implementation of these services can be seen &#8212; at least in part &#8212; as a proactive defense against potential legislation. Essentially something companies can point to as a way of showing that, actually, they\u2019re on the consumers\u2019 side with this one.<\/p>\n<p>The service is slated to arrive this summer.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Last year, Apple proved it could still surprise when it announced a Self Service Repair plan. The offering is still limited, and the company &#8212; as ever &#8212; recommends users take their products in to get fixed, rather than potentially damaging them further. Even so, it marked a major shift for a company that has [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":699688,"featured_media":2266431,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"c55737fa-5900-3fd6-9a47-030f9ffdc898"},"categories":[449223024,449557028,17396],"tags":[1992178,576613174,32518],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/02\/CMC_0904.jpg","parsely":{"version":"1.0.0","meta":{"@context":"http:\/\/schema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","mainEntityOfPage":{"@type":"WebPage","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/31\/as-right-to-repair-legislation-looms-samsung-introduces-self-service-for-galaxy-devices\/"},"headline":"As tps:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=449557028"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=449557028"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=449557028"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":17396,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tc\/","name":"TC","slug":"tc","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/17396"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=17396"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":1992178,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/ifixit\/","name":"ifixit","slug":"ifixit","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/1992178"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=1992178"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=1992178"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=1992178"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=1992178"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576613174,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/right-to-repair\/","name":"right to repair","slug":"right-to-repair","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576613174"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576613174"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576613174"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576613174"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576613174"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":32518,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/samsung\/","name":"Samsung","slug":"samsung","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/32518"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=32518"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=32518"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=32518"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=32518"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2291710,"date":"2022-03-31T09:00:42","date_gmt":"2022-03-31T16:00:42","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2291710"},"modified":"2022-03-30T12:31:57","modified_gmt":"2022-03-30T19:31:57","slug":"freestyle-fund-6-jenny-lefcourt-dave-samuel","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/31\/freestyle-fund-6-jenny-lefcourt-dave-samuel\/","title":{"rendered":"For Freestyle&#8217;s newest fund, the growth hack is staying the same"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">Freestyle, a venture<\/span> capital firm that has cut early checks into companies such as Airtable, Patreon, BetterUp and Narvar, has closed its sixth fund at $130 million.<\/p>\n<p>The newest fund is also the firm\u2019s largest investment vehicle to date, but still feels tiny compared to <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/08\/27\/andreessen-horowitz-just-rolled-out-a-400-million-fund-thats-expressly-for-seed-deals\/\">Andreessen Horowitz\u2019s $400 million seed fund<\/a> or <a href=\"https:\/\/greylock.com\/firm-news\/500m-for-seeds\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Greylock\u2019s $500 million seed fund. <\/a>However, per general partner Jenny Lefcourt, the conservative raise was intentional: The growth hack, for the 2009-founded firm, is to stay the same despite valuation and check-size pressure from the broader early-stage market.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cFund size ends up dictating strategy,\u201d Lefcourt said. If Freestyle raised a $500 million seed fund, Lefcourt explained, the firm would have to flip its model, hire associates and focus on investing in more founders versus working deeper with a select few. \u201cIt\u2019s tempting to raise a bigger fund when people want to give you money, but you could get addicted to management fees instead of carry.\u201d<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2291710\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>Indeed, Freestyle stands out for sticking to its original investment strategy, even with today\u2019s newly announced fund. The firm leads less than a dozen seed rounds per year, aims for 10% to 15% ownership and bets across all verticals. Freestyle has slightly grown its check size year over year to stay on a similar cadence, with its average bet between $1.5 million to $3 million. Despite web3 companies, which Lefcourt says they invest in despite ownership and valuation differences, Freestyle doesn\u2019t go for \u201cbuzzy companies\u201d with high valuations &#8212; which it considers above $20 million.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cWe both felt like we\u2019ve seen how this movie ends, and high valuations too early have actually caused trouble down the road for the vast majority of founders,\u201d said Lefcourt, who led the firm\u2019s investments in BetterUp, Narvar and Daily. \u201cWhile the quantity in deal flow has definitely gone up, the quality in aggregate is lower.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>The firm does boast one (unfortunately) contrarian characteristic, though: ownership is split half and half between partners Jenny Lefcourt and Dave Samuel. Despite the steady rise of female check-writers, Lefcourt pointed out that within institutional firms, the title &#8220;partner&#8221; doesn\u2019t always come with true ownership or decision-making capabilities. About 43% of portfolio companies have a historically under-represented founder and co-founder, which Freestyle defines as non-white males and women of any race and ethnicity. About 29% of current fund companies have a woman founder and\/or co-founder.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2291725\" style=\"width: 857px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2291725\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"breakout wp-image-2291725\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Dave_Jenny_HiRes-Yellow.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"847\" height=\"984\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Dave_Jenny_HiRes-Yellow.png 3273w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Dave_Jenny_HiRes-Yellow.png?resize=129,150 129w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Dave_Jenny_HiRes-Yellow.png?resize=258,300 258w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Dave_Jenny_HiRes-Yellow.png?resize=768,893 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Dave_Jenny_HiRes-Yellow.png?resize=585,680 585w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Dave_Jenny_HiRes-Yellow.png?resize=1321,1536 1321w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Dave_Jenny_HiRes-Yellow.png?resize=1762,2048 1762w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Dave_Jenny_HiRes-Yellow.png?resize=43,50 43w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 847px) 100vw, 847px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2291725\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Jenny Lefcourt and Dave Samuel, the general partners of Freestyle. <strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Freestyle<\/p><\/div><\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Last year, the firm\u2019s co-founder Josh Felser left to start another venture capital firm, this time with an explicit focus on<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/12\/06\/climactic-raj-kapoor-josh-felser\/\"> startups tackling climate change<\/a>. His new firm, Climactic, seems to be following an entirely different playbook than Freestyle: It has employed a number of consultants who have been former heads of sales and marketing at other companies, hasn\u2019t yet raised a formal fund and participates in rounds.<\/p>\n<p>The departure hasn\u2019t seemed to hurt limited partner interest in Freestyle. The firm\u2019s new fund came together in a month, all from existing investors, and the team was able to hire CFO <a href=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/joshua-gilbert-5b746329\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Josh Gilbert<\/a> from Lerer Hippeau. Despite this momentum, Lefcourt seems to know that Freestyle could use some attention, given competition from all the newer funds.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cIf you go back to the earlier days, people in the industry really knew that Freestyle was an amazing seed fund,\u201d she said. \u201cNow, Silicon Valley is everywhere and we realize that we have to make the world know we\u2019re here just a little bit more than maybe we\u2019re used to.\u201d<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Freestyle, a venture capital firm that has cut early checks into companies such as Airtable, Patreon, BetterUp and Narvar, has closed its sixth fund at $130 million. The newest fund is also the firm\u2019s largest investment vehicle to date, but still feels tiny compared to Andreessen Horowitz\u2019s $400 million seed fund or Greylock\u2019s $500 million [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574362,"featured_media":1665943,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"f347afad-a8ce-3a9e-917a-8a91c7f7a26a"},"categories":[576602978,17396,35394854],"tags":[40979833,51813757,36665853],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/GettyImages-699087378.jpg","parsely":{"version":"1.0.0","meta":{"@context":"http:\/\/schema.org","@type":"WebPage","headline":"Viasat capital","slug":"freestyle-capital","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/40979833"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=40979833"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=40979833"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=40979833"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=40979833"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":51813757,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/jenny-lefcourt\/","name":"Jenny Lefcourt","slug":"jenny-lefcourt","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/51813757"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=51813757"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=51813757"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=51813757"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=51813757"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":36665853,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/venture-2\/","name":"venture","slug":"venture-2","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/36665853"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=36665853"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=36665853"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=36665853"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=36665853"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2292099,"date":"2022-03-31T09:00:25","date_gmt":"2022-03-31T16:00:25","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2292099"},"modified":"2022-03-31T14:36:34","modified_gmt":"2022-03-31T21:36:34","slug":"instagram-upgrades-its-dm-inbox-with-music-sharing-statuses-polls-silent-messages-and-more","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/31\/instagram-upgrades-its-dm-inbox-with-music-sharing-statuses-polls-silent-messages-and-more\/","title":{"rendered":"Instagram upgrades its DM inbox with music sharing, statuses, polls, silent messages and more"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Instagram today is rolling out over a half dozen new messaging features, following <a href=\"https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/reel\/CYCWNztgL6v\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">promises<\/a> late last year that its DM (direct message) inbox would get a significant upgrade in 2022. The changes include the ability to share music previews in DMs, the ability to send a message silently, the ability to see who&#8217;s online to chat with, the ability to reply to messages while you browse your feed and more.<\/p>\n<p>The company says the work is part of its larger efforts to improve how users connect and share with friends. It also comes on the heels of <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/23\/instagram-launches-chronological-and-favorites-feeds-for-all-users-but-they-cant-be-the-default\/\">Instagram&#8217;s launch of chronological feed options<\/a>, Following and Favorites, which allow users to see posts ranked without the use of algorithms. The Favorites feed allows users to hand-select a list of their closest friends or favorite creators to keep closer track of, while the Following option simply sorts posts in chronological order.<\/p>\n<p>Now Instagram is turning its attention to the inbox. Today&#8217;s <a href=\"https:\/\/about.fb.com\/news\/2022\/03\/introducing-new-instagram-messaging-features\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">changes<\/a> include the following:<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2292099\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Music sharing:<\/strong> Instagram will integrate with Apple Music, Amazon Music and, soon, Spotify, to allow users to share 30-second song previews in chats.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Reply while browsing:<\/strong> The app will allow you to reply to new messages while browsing their Feed, without having to go to the inbox and lose your place.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Quick sending:<\/strong> You can now tap and hold the share button to quickly reshare posts to your closest four friends.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Status:<\/strong> At the top of your inbox, you can now see who&#8217;s free to chat with, similar to Messenger.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Silent messages:<\/strong> You can opt to send messages to friends without bothering them &#8212; like when you know they&#8217;re busy or asleep. To do so, you&#8217;ll add &#8220;@silent&#8221; to your message.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Lo-fi chat theme:<\/strong> A new theme designed to make conversations feel more personal, which features a cityscape scene and a cat.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Polls:<\/strong> You can now use the Poll sticker to create a poll directly in the group chat.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2292123\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2292123\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2292123\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/15.-Q1-Bundle-1_A-1200x675-1.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"383\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/15.-Q1-Bundle-1_A-1200x675-1.png 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/15.-Q1-Bundle-1_A-1200x675-1.png?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/15.-Q1-Bundle-1_A-1200x675-1.png?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/15.-Q1-Bundle-1_A-1200x675-1.png?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/15.-Q1-Bundle-1_A-1200x675-1.png?resize=680,383 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/15.-Q1-Bundle-1_A-1200x675-1.png?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2292123\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Instagram<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>We should note that some of these new features require users to upgrade to Instagram&#8217;s <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/09\/30\/facebook-introduces-cross-app-communication-between-messenger-and-instagram-plus-other-features\/\">upgraded messaging experience first introduced in fall 2020,<\/a> allowing for cross-app communication between Instagram and Messenger. As part of this upgrade, Instagram&#8217;s inbox received several more features, including the ability to change the chat color, react with emojis, co-watch videos and more. The company confirmed to us that only music sharing, the new chat theme and the quick-send features will work if users haven&#8217;t yet opted-in to the upgraded messaging experience.<\/p>\n<p>The DM update follows Instagram&#8217;s decision to <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/11\/17\/instagram-will-shut-down-its-companion-app-threads-by-year-end\/\">close down its companion messaging app<\/a> called Threads in December 2021. The company said at the time it planned to bring Threads&#8217; unique features to the main Instagram app in the future. Instagram also explained that consolidating its efforts around messaging in one app made more sense, in terms of time and resources.<\/p>\n<p>Instagram included messaging as a key area of focus for 2022, alongside other priorities, like video, controls and creator monetization efforts. In the same update where Instagram head Adam Mosseri <a href=\"https:\/\/www.theverge.com\/2021\/6\/30\/22557942\/instagram-no-longer-photo-app-video-entertainment-focus\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">proclaimed<\/a> in December that Instagram was &#8220;no longer a photo-sharing app,&#8221; he also spoke about the company&#8217;s plans for private communications. Messaging is &#8220;the primary way people connect online at this point,&#8221; he said. &#8220;We think Instagram can be the best place for people to connect with their friends about their interests, and Instagram is to embrace the fact that messaging is that primary form of communication,&#8221; Mosseri explained.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>The Instagram inbox isn&#8217;t the only Meta-owned messaging product being upgraded this week. Just yesterday, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/29\/messenger-shortcuts-everyone-feature\/\">Messenger introduced Slack-like &#8220;@everyone&#8221; functionality<\/a> that will notify all participants in a chat about a new message, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/29\/messenger-shortcuts-everyone-feature\/\">and other shortcuts<\/a> like a &#8220;\/silent&#8221; feature, similar to Instagram&#8217;s &#8220;@silent,&#8221; and more. WhatsApp, meanwhile, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/30\/people-are-sending-7-billion-voice-messages-on-whatsapp-every-day\/\">upgraded its voice message functionality<\/a> with several new features yesterday, as well.<\/p>\n<p>Instagram says its new DM features will be available in select countries at launch, but will expand globally in time.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Instagram today is rolling out over a half dozen new messaging features, following promises late last year that its DM (direct message) inbox would get a significant upgrade in 2022. The changes include the ability to share music previews in DMs, the ability to send a message silently, the ability to see who&#8217;s online to out how AWS, Brex, Mayfield and Dell can help your company scale at TC Early Stage"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">If there\u2019s one thing you\u2019ll get out of attending <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-early-stage-2022\/?promo=partnersessionpostmar31\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">TC Early Stage<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u00a0in San Francisco on April 14, it\u2019s an accelerated education in the essentials of building a successful startup.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Seasoned founders and industry experts cover a range of topics \u2014 find your product-market fit, develop your target customer personas, get feedback on your pitch deck, learn how to tell your story in a way that makes investors take notice and so much more.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><b>Don\u2019t delay:<\/b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> We\u2019re running low on $249 founder passes. <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-early-stage-2022\/?promo=partnersessionpostmar31&amp;display=true\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Buy your pass today and save $200<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> \u2014 once they\u2019re gone, the price goes up.<\/span><\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2291010\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-early-stage-2022\/?promo=partnersessionpostmar31#a4189c79-f7f6-43ce-89bb-5cc1b32e3ec3\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The event agenda<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> is packed with more than 40 presentations focused on funding, marketing\/PR and operations, but we want to take a moment to offer this piece of advice. Don\u2019t miss out on our partner sessions. These expert-led, topic-specific breakouts give you time to lean in, ask more questions, get more answers, connect with companies that support early-stage startups and discover new opportunities and potential strategic partnerships.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">We\u2019ve got an impressive array of partners ready to strut their stuff. Take a look at who\u2019s coming and what you&#8217;ll learn from them.<\/span><\/p>\n<h3><span class=\"schedule-item__title\">Evolving from Scientist to Founder<\/span><\/h3>\n<p><em>Brought to you by <span class=\"sponsors-label__sponsor-name\"><a href=\"https:\/\/www.mayfield.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Mayfield<\/a><\/span><\/em><\/p>\n<p><span class=\"schedule-item__description\">How do you go from PhD to startup founder and beyond? In this session, Mammoth Biosciences co-founder &amp; CTO Janice Chen and Endpoint Health co-founder &amp; CSO Diego Rey join Mayfield\u2019s Ursheet Parikh to share learnings from their own scientist-to-founder growth journeys. Learn how to go from bench to bedside and leverage scientific breakthroughs to save lives, how startups can ink productive partnerships with industry behemoths and more.<\/span><\/p>\n<h3><span class=\"schedule-item__title\">Financial stacks that scale from MVP to IPO<\/span><\/h3>\n<p><em>Brought to you by <span class=\"sponsors-label__sponsor-name\"><a href=\"https:\/\/brex.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Brex<\/a><\/span><\/em><\/p>\n<p><span class=\"schedule-item__description\">The best startup founders are visionaries &#8212; not operators. But the most successful startups are built to scale operationally from Day 1. In this panel discussion, Brex\u2019s directors of Product share their insights on the personal and practical choices early founders can make to streamline financial reporting and make their future CFOs proud. Even better? You can spend less time budgeting and more time building.<\/span><\/p>\n<h3><span class=\"schedule-item__title\">How to Talk Business When You\u2019re a Technical Founder<\/span><\/h3>\n<p><em>Brought to you by <span class=\"sponsors-label__sponsor-name\"><a href=\"https:\/\/www.dell.com\/en-us\/work\/shop\/techcrunch\/cp\/techcrunch\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Dell for Startups<\/a><\/span><\/em><\/p>\n<p><span class=\"schedule-item__description\">When it comes to pitching early-stage enterprise startups, technical founders can sometimes neglect the business side of the conversation. To help build your confidence in \u201ctalking business,\u201d DTC\u2019s Ryan Wexler will cover the fundamentals of what investors want to hear about how you\u2019ll transform your technology into a fundamentally important business.<\/span><\/p>\n<h3><span class=\"schedule-item__title\">Top 10 Mistakes Early Founders Make<\/span><\/h3>\n<p><em>Brought to you by <span class=\"sponsors-label__sponsor-name\"><a href=\"http:\/\/aws.com\/startups\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon Web Services<\/a><\/span><\/em><\/p>\n<p><span class=\"schedule-item__description\">What are the top mistakes early founders make while they are trying to reach product-market fit and how do you avoid them? In this presentation, Omar Valle will distill the lessons he has learned while working with over a thousand early-stage startups from top accelerators like Y Combinator, Techstars and StartX.<\/span><\/p>\n<h3><strong><span class=\"schedule-item__title\">Building a Web3 Platform Company<\/span><\/strong><\/h3>\n<p><em>Brought to you by <span class=\"sponsors-label__sponsor-name\"><a href=\"https:\/\/www.mayfield.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Mayfield<\/a><\/span><\/em><\/p>\n<p><span class=\"schedule-item__description\">How do you build a web3 platform company? Joe Lau, co-founder &amp; CTO of the world\u2019s leading blockchain developer platform Alchemy, joins Mayfield MD Navin Chaddha to share learnings from Alchemy\u2019s journey from inception to iconic. Join this session to learn about the inspiration behind Alchemy, how to find product-market fit in an emerging market, how to embed dev-centric into your DNA and more.<\/span><\/p>\n<h3><span class=\"schedule-item__title\">Setting the Foundation for Built-to-Last Companies<\/span><\/h3>\n<p><em>Brought to you by <span class=\"sponsors-label__sponsor-name\"><a href=\"https:\/\/www.mayfield.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Mayfield<\/a><\/span><\/em><\/p>\n<p><span class=\"schedule-item__description\">When it comes to company building, some things can\u2019t be retrofitted &#8212; they have to be set in place from day one. Join this session with Outreach co-founder &amp; CEO Manny Medina and Mayfield\u2019s Rajeev Batra as they share insights from Outreach\u2019s inception to iconic journey, including lessons learned on building an empathetic performance culture, embedding DEI into your DNA, the playbook for great category design and more.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-early-stage-2022\/?promo=partnersessionpostmar31\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">TechCrunch Early Stage<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u00a0takes place live and in-person on April 14. <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-early-stage-2022\/?promo=partnersessionpostmar31&amp;display=true\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Buy your pass now <\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">while you can save $200 and get ready for startup bootcamp. We can\u2019t wait to see you 2022","slug":"tc-early-stage-2022","taxonomy":"tc_event","rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event\/576869965"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_event"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event\/576715145"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_event=576869965"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_events?tc_event=576869965"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tc_event=576869965"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}]]}},{"id":2292163,"date":"2022-03-31T08:50:32","date_gmt":"2022-03-31T15:50:32","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2292163"},"modified":"2022-03-31T09:49:30","modified_gmt":"2022-03-31T16:49:30","slug":"yelp-restaurant-health-ratings-in-partnership-with-food-tech-startup-hazel-analytics","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/31\/yelp-restaurant-health-ratings-in-partnership-with-food-tech-startup-hazel-analytics\/","title":{"rendered":"Yelp expands restaurant health ratings in partnership with food tech startup Hazel Analytics"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Yelp is broadening its partnership with Seattle-based food tech startup <a href=\"https:\/\/hazelanalytics.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Hazel Analytics<\/a> to expand health ratings on its platform, the company <a href=\"https:\/\/blog.yelp.com\/news\/yelp-partners-with-hazel-analytics-to-display-health-inspection-data-across-the-us-and-canada\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">announced<\/a> on Thursday. The two companies are working together to further expand Yelp&#8217;s health grades information on restaurant listings. Yelp <a href=\"https:\/\/hazelanalytics.com\/yelp\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">first partnered<\/a> with Hazel Analytics last year to display inspection details for restaurants on its platform.<\/p>\n<p>Hazel Analytics now provides the hygiene data on nearly 700,000 Yelp pages, and lists information about health inspection jurisdictions representing nearly 70% of the U.S. population. This feature incorporates data from health departments across 48 states, up from four states previously. For the first time, the feature will bring Canadian health scores to Yelp, with data from Toronto and Vancouver.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2292224\" style=\"width: 503px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2292224\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\" wp-image-2292224\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Letter-Grade-Powered-by-Hazel-Analytics.gif\" alt=\"\" width=\"493\" height=\"493\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2292224\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Yelp<\/p><\/div><\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2292163\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>&#8220;The expansion of Yelp\u2019s health scores program\u00a0comes at a time when people are returning to indoor dining as COVID-19 restrictions continue to lift,\u00a0health inspections are bouncing back\u00a0from the early pandemic pause, and restaurants continue to embrace diner safety measures like\u00a0contactless payments and virtual menus,&#8221; the company said in a blog post about the announcement.<\/p>\n<p>Hazel Analytics collects health scores from local health departments&#8217; publicly available data. In instances where a health department doesn&#8217;t publish a score as part of its health inspection findings, Hazel Analytics uses underlying data to estimate a score based on a 100-point scoring system to show how a business\u2019s latest inspection compares to others in the same jurisdiction.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cSince our founding, the mission of Hazel Analytics has been to improve public health by connecting food service businesses, regulators and consumers,\u201d said Arash Nasibi, the co-founder and CEO at Hazel Analytics, in a statement. \u201cAfter years of providing award-winning technology solutions to enterprise food safety professionals, we\u2019re now excited to partner with Yelp to make it easier than ever for consumers to have access to local dining establishments\u2019 public health inspection information.\u201d<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"Ic3pvV8Piu\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/11\/09\/yelps-new-ios-home-feed-makes-it-easier-to-discover-local-restaurants\/\">Yelp&#8217;s new iOS home feed makes it easier to discover local restaurants<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Yelp&#8217;s new iOS home feed makes it easier to discover local restaurants&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/11\/09\/yelps-new-ios-home-feed-makes-it-easier-to-discover-local-restaurants\/embed\/#?secret=nvj8h777kv#?secret=Ic3pvV8Piu\" data-secret=\"Ic3pvV8Piu\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Yelp is broadening its partnership with Seattle-based food tech startup Hazel Analytics to expand health ratings on its platform, the company announced on Thursday. The two companies are working together to further expand Yelp&#8217;s health grades information on restaurant listings. Yelp first partnered with Hazel Analytics last year to display inspection details for restaurants on Analytics","slug":"hazel-analytics","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/577000581"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=577000581"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=577000581"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=577000581"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=577000581"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":449557042,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/startups\/","name":"Startups","slug":"startups","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449557042"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449557042"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":246990,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/yelp\/","name":"Yelp","slug":"yelp","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/246990"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=246990"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=246990"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=246990"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=246990"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2292052,"date":"2022-03-31T08:00:13","date_gmt":"2022-03-31T15:00:13","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2292052"},"modified":"2022-03-31T06:25:24","modified_gmt":"2022-03-31T13:25:24","slug":"as-docker-gains-momentum-it-hauls-in-105m-series-c-on-2b-valuation","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/31\/as-docker-gains-momentum-it-hauls-in-105m-series-c-on-2b-valuation\/","title":{"rendered":"As Docker gains momentum, it hauls in $105M Series C on $2B valuation"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">It wasn&#8217;t that long ago that <a href=\"http:\/\/docker.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Docker<\/a> looked like it was on the ropes. In 2019, it <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/11\/13\/mirantis-acquires-docker-enterprise\/\">sold its enterprise business<\/a> and decided to focus strictly <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/03\/10\/docker-regroups-as-cloud-native-developer-tool-company\/\">on a developer audience<\/a> with a set of commercial and open source tools. It was a pretty big bet for a six-year-old company to sell off the part of itself that was most lucrative at the time and completely shift its focus.<\/p>\n<p>A couple of months ago, the company announced that annual recurring revenue (ARR) <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/02\/01\/docker-makes-comeback-reaching-over-50m-in-arr\/\">had jumped 4x to over $50 million<\/a> just two years after it decided to restructure. Today, the company announced a $105 million Series C investment on a $2.1 billion valuation.<\/p>\n<p>CEO Scott Johnston, who has been with the company for years in various capacities, made a very clear bet on the developer community, and it is paying off handsomely for him as he has been able to shape a successful business model since the restructuring.<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2292052\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>&#8220;Two and a half years ago, while we had this product that developers loved; while we had popular upstream open source assets and we had a known brand, it wasn&#8217;t clear whether we could take all of that and redo the product strategy we needed to go to market, redo the company business model successfully &#8212; all of that was an open question,&#8221; Johnston said.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;We&#8217;re happy that here we are two and a half years later. We didn&#8217;t make perfect decisions or perfect bets all the time, but most of our bets have paid off and are serving developers with the products we&#8217;re shipping,&#8221; he said.<\/p>\n<p>What&#8217;s more, in a time when investment appears to be slowing down, Johnston reports that investors came to him, he had a wealth of opportunity and could have gotten more if he wanted it. &#8220;It was unsolicited, and we had choice. We had multiple term sheets that were all competitive. And we could have raised more than 105 that we raised. And so we&#8217;re very fortunate to be able to choose.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>He believes that in addition to being a known quantity with an open source component that is popular with developers, the potential market for developer tools is massive, especially as the demand for applications continues to grow. He said the combination of those two factors drove the investor interest in this round.<\/p>\n<p>The company shrank to 70 people when it restructured in 2019. Today it is up to over 150 employees with expectations that number will double in the next year. As the company adds headcount, Johnston said that they have hard metrics related to building a diverse workforce.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;So we have an internal KPI, key performance indicator, that&#8217;s quantified in terms of diversity. And we have it at the company level, but then each of the managers, the executives for their functions, are on that as well. And again, to put teeth on it, that&#8217;s a number that we had to share with the board as well,&#8221; he said.<\/p>\n<p>He said that they look at this on a weekly basis. &#8220;We have a weekly roll-up of our progress in our hiring and recruiting funnel and there&#8217;s an explicit diversity metric in that weekly recruiting. And so, you know, it goes back to the why, right? And that&#8217;s because diverse teams are better teams. It&#8217;s better not only from a human standpoint, but it&#8217;s better frankly from a capitalist performance standpoint. So we deeply believe that and to execute that belief, we hold ourselves accountable numerically,&#8221; he said.<\/p>\n<p>Today&#8217;s investment was led by new investor Bain Capital Ventures with participation from Atlassian Ventures, Citi Ventures, Vertex Ventures and Four Rivers, along with existing investors Benchmark Capital, Insight Partners and Tribe Capital. The company has raised $163 million in its current guise on that $2.1 billion valuation. Bain&#8217;s Enrique Salem will be joining the Docker board under the terms of the agreement.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"BmZudcn4je\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/02\/01\/docker-makes-comeback-reaching-over-50m-in-arr\/\">Docker makes comeback with over $50M in ARR two years into restructuring<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Docker makes comeback with over $50M in ARR two years into restructuring&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/02\/01\/docker-makes-comeback-reaching-over-50m-in-arr\/embed\/#?secret=fEAJyWrLtt#?secret=BmZudcn4je\" data-secret=\"BmZudcn4je\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>It wasn&#8217;t that long ago that Docker looked like it was on the ropes. In 2019, it sold its enterprise business and decided to focus strictly on a developer audience with a set of commercial and open source tools. It was a pretty big bet for a six-year-old company to sell off the part of source","slug":"open-source","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/25"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=25"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=25"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=25"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=25"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576713822,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/scott-johnston\/","name":"Scott Johnston","slug":"scott-johnston","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576713822"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576713822"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576713822"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576713822"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576713822"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2292111,"date":"2022-03-31T07:08:55","date_gmt":"2022-03-31T14:08:55","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2292111"},"modified":"2022-03-31T08:15:37","modified_gmt":"2022-03-31T15:15:37","slug":"google-search-label-original-news-sources","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/31\/google-search-label-original-news-sources\/","title":{"rendered":"Google Search is getting a new label to direct people to original news sources"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Google is adding a new &#8220;highly cited&#8221; label in Search results to direct users to trusted sources, the company <a href=\"https:\/\/blog.google\/products\/news\/fact-checking-misinformation-google-features\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">announced<\/a> on Thursday. The new label, which will appear in the Top Stories carousel, is designed to help users identify stories that have been frequently cited by other news organizations. The highly cited label is launching soon on mobile in the United States and will roll out globally in the coming weeks.<\/p>\n<p>The label will be placed on investigative articles, interviews, announcements, press releases, local news stories and more. Google says it&#8217;s particularly interested in how the label can be used to elevate original reporting.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Let\u2019s say a local news organization breaks an investigative story looking into problems at your local school district,&#8221; the company said in a blog post. &#8220;The story is so big that it gets picked up by numerous other media outlets. But what if you didn\u2019t see that original story, which had unique context for local residents? We\u2019re introducing a way to help you identify stories that have been frequently cited by other news organizations, giving you a simple way to find the most helpful or relevant information for a news story.&#8221;<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2292111\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>In addition to launching the new highly cited label, Google is also expanding its &#8220;rapidly evolving topics&#8221; notice that appears alongside breaking news in search results to indicate that it can take time for information to be published. Starting today, searches in English in the United States will include tips to help users evaluate information online and remind them to check whether a source is trusted on a topic or come back later when there&#8217;s more information available.<\/p>\n<p>Today&#8217;s announcement comes a day after <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/30\/google-rolls-out-a-i-improvements-to-aid-with-search-safety-and-personal-crisis-queries\/\">Google said<\/a> it&#8217;s rolling out improvements to its AI model to make Google Search a safer experience and one that\u2019s better at handling sensitive queries, including those around topics like suicide, sexual assault, substance abuse and domestic violence. It\u2019s also using other AI technologies to improve its ability to remove unwanted explicit or suggestive content from Search results when people aren\u2019t specifically seeking it out.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"0LFucgnj7r\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/30\/google-rolls-out-a-i-improvements-to-aid-with-search-safety-and-personal-crisis-queries\/\">Google rolls out AI improvements to aid with Search safety and &#8216;personal crisis&#8217; queries<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Google rolls out AI improvements to aid with Search safety and &#8216;personal crisis&#8217; queries&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/30\/google-rolls-out-a-i-improvements-to-aid-with-search-safety-and-personal-crisis-queries\/embed\/#?secret=ANa9or6vOB#?secret=0LFucgnj7r\" data-secret=\"0LFucgnj7r\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Google is adding a new &#8220;highly cited&#8221; label in Search results to direct users to trusted sources, the company announced on Thursday. The new label, which will appear in the Top Stories carousel, is designed to help users identify stories that have been frequently cited by other news organizations. The highly cited label is launching search","slug":"google-search","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/1292"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=1292"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=1292"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=1292"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=1292"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":20115,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/google-news\/","name":"Google-News","slug":"google-news","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/20115"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=20115"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=20115"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=20115"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=20115"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2292108,"date":"2022-03-31T06:56:04","date_gmt":"2022-03-31T13:56:04","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2292108"},"modified":"2022-03-31T08:25:06","modified_gmt":"2022-03-31T15:25:06","slug":"womens-leadership-network-chief-surges-to-unicorn-status","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/31\/womens-leadership-network-chief-surges-to-unicorn-status\/","title":{"rendered":"Women&#8217;s leadership network Chief surges to unicorn status"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">As Ariana Grande would say, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/watch?v=kHLHSlExFis\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">god is a woman<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>So it should come as no surprise that <a href=\"https:\/\/chief.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Chief<\/a>, the network designed to develop the leadership skills of women, has hit a $1.1 billion valuation in a matter of three years.<\/p>\n<p>The startup, led by founders Carolyn Childers and Lindsay Kaplan, just raised a $100 million Series B round led by Alphabet&#8217;s CapitalG. Partner Laela Sturdy will join the board as part of the deal. Other investors in the round include General Catalyst, GGV Capital, Inspired Capital, Primary Ventures and Flybridge.<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2292108\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>Chief has now raised a total of $140 million.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"scerRmfyv1\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/21\/chief-the-leadership-network-for-women-raises-15-million-in-funding\/\">Chief, the leadership network for women, raises $15 million in funding<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Chief, the leadership network for women, raises $15 million in funding&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/21\/chief-the-leadership-network-for-women-raises-15-million-in-funding\/embed\/#?secret=dvPr5cyOcG#?secret=scerRmfyv1\" data-secret=\"scerRmfyv1\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>Though the company didn&#8217;t specify numerically, it said in a release that it grew significantly through the pandemic after going virtual, and was able to more easily expand nationally in that format.<\/p>\n<p>As it stands now, Chief membership counts more than 12,000 senior executives from more than 8,500 companies, including HBO, American Express, Nike, Google, Goldman Sachs, NASA, Chobani, Pfizer, Apple and more. The startup says it has more than 60,000 women around the world hanging out on the waitlist.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>This raise comes at a time when professional development is heating up. Companies like Medley and <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/11\/02\/hone-a-human-powered-platform-for-leadership-training-nabs-16-million\/\">Hone<\/a> have both raised recently. LinkedIn has <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/linkedin-doubles-down-on-development-with-new-learning-hub-free-courses-and-new-search-fields-for-hybrid-working\/\">doubled down on development with a new learning hub<\/a>. And many other companies have sprouted up in the past several years to grab a piece of the pie, including <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/04\/03\/torch-executive-coaching\/\">Torch<\/a>, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/20\/smb-mentorship-platform-ureeka-raises-8-6m-will-facilitate-grant-programs-for-facebook-salesforce\/\">Ureeka<\/a> and <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/16\/rising-team-with-3-million-seed-is-a-platform-that-combines-management-tools-with-training\/\">Rising Team<\/a>, to name a few.<\/p>\n<p>It&#8217;s a hot space, and Chief is now capitalized to move aggressively and capture the market.<\/p>\n<p>Also, in case you&#8217;re interested, check out our <a href=\"https:\/\/podcasts.apple.com\/us\/podcast\/found-live-ft-jordan-taylor-and-edith-cooper-medley\/id1561051074?i=1000551762152\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">episode of the Found podcast with Medley co-founders Edith Cooper and Jordan Taylor here<\/a>.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>As Ariana Grande would say, god is a woman. So it should come as no surprise that Chief, the network designed to develop the leadership skills of women, has hit a $1.1 billion valuation in a matter of three years. The startup, led by founders Carolyn Childers and Lindsay Kaplan, just raised a $100 million kaplan","slug":"lindsay-kaplan","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576769506"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576769506"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576769506"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576769506"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576769506"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":449557042,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/startups\/","name":"Startups","slug":"startups","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449557042"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449557042"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2292058,"date":"2022-03-31T06:49:10","date_gmt":"2022-03-31T13:49:10","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2292058"},"modified":"2022-03-31T06:49:10","modified_gmt":"2022-03-31T13:49:10","slug":"is-it-time-to-start-worrying-about-startup-layoffs","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/31\/is-it-time-to-start-worrying-about-startup-layoffs\/","title":{"rendered":"Is it time to start worrying about startup layoffs?"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">Startups are once<\/span> again considering layoffs as a way to control cash consumption and attract new capital.<\/p>\n<p>News that Fast, a one-click checkout software provider targeting the e-commerce market, is <a href=\"https:\/\/www.theinformation.com\/articles\/stripe-backed-fast-puts-job-cuts-on-the-table-as-it-tries-to-raise-money\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">offering sharp staff cuts to investors<\/a> in hopes of securing new capital is notable, but a single data point. A public database tracking startup layoffs, however, indicates that the company is not alone in looking to reduce its headcount.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong><em>The Exchange explores startups, markets and money. <\/em><\/strong><\/p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong><em>Read it <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/subscribe\/?tpcc=theexchange\">every morning on TechCrunch+<\/a> or get <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters\">The Exchange newsletter<\/a> every Saturday.<\/em><\/strong><\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p>It&#8217;s doubtful that accelerating staff reductions will make the startup labor market dramatically less talent-friendly. Startups are not the only companies in the market hiring technology workers. Upstart technology firms must compete with both industry incumbents, like Apple and Microsoft, for talent, as well as traditional firms building out their own in-house engineering and data teams. So it&#8217;s likely that even as startups trim staff, the labor market for tech workers remains more than temperate.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/subscribe\/?tpcc=theexchange\"><img loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignright wp-image-2220368 size-medium\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/10\/exchange-banner-sq-gry-plus.jpg?w=300\" alt=\"\" width=\"300\" height=\"300\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/10\/exchange-banner-sq-gry-plus.jpg 900w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/10\/exchange-banner-sq-gry-plus.jpg?resize=150,150 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/10\/exchange-banner-sq-gry-plus.jpg?resize=300,300 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/10\/exchange-banner-sq-gry-plus.jpg?resize=768,768 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/10\/exchange-banner-sq-gry-plus.jpg?resize=680,680 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/10\/exchange-banner-sq-gry-plus.jpg?resize=32,32 32w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/10\/exchange-banner-sq-gry-plus.jpg?resize=50,50 50w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/10\/exchange-banner-sq-gry-plus.jpg?resize=64,64 64w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/10\/exchange-banner-sq-gry-plus.jpg?resize=96,96 96w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/10\/exchange-banner-sq-gry-plus.jpg?resize=128,128 128w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" \/><\/a>But cutting headcount is a quick way to cut burn and extend runway. If cash is business oxygen, laying staff off lets a company breathe more slowly, extending its life expectancy without an infusion of external capital (air).<\/p>\n<p>It doesn&#8217;t seem likely that we&#8217;re on the precipice of a similar spike in layoffs that the onset of COVID-19 brought in 2020. That moment is essentially impossible to reconstitute in business terms. This time around, folks better know what is coming. Changing public market valuations for tech companies and a frozen IPO market have soured private-market sentiment concerning high-growth, high-burn startups. But the damage will accrete more slowly, as startups are each on a different cash countdown, meaning that their respective hard choices about staffing levels won&#8217;t occur at once.<\/p>\n<p>Let&#8217;s take a quick moment to consider the latest state of the Fast saga, skate through recent startup layoffs to see if we can spy a trend, and ask what we&#8217;re going to see in Q2.<\/p>\n<p><div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Startups are once again considering layoffs as a way to control cash consumption and attract new
